column5:
So today I went to the doctor for a check up. My brother and grandpa accompanied me. It hadn't come up in a while, but I knew it would. My grandpa mentioned my weight, and the doctor whipped out the BMI chart. It was a bit confusing but he basically said, "You can eat more." And I was like, Okey. And he suggested multivitamins. But my family is in debate whether he said "Multivitamins with Iron." Or "Something with Iron." Basically I need Iron. And we went to the store to try to find some, but I got upset because I couldn't find any without gelatin. (I am vegetarian and gelatin is made from animal fat/bones.)
And we found something with ONLY iron, but no other vitamins. My family was like, "Its just gelatin, and if you can't handle just a little animal if it helps your help we will make you stop being a vegetarian!"
It made me upset that they tried to control what I eat, and the mention of my weight came up again. Its just a little frustrating when your weight/diet is always under a microscope.
column9: Hi leonardfluddatw72, we edited your comment slightly to remove an outside link, which is not allowed on the forums – you can review our community guidelines here. Thank you for understanding and please continue to post!

column5:
I was wondering if anyone else has experienced this.
I have recently gone to treatment, and have been weight restored for around 5 months. Before treatment, my hair was falling out. I probably lost about 1/3 of my hair. But now, since I have been eating properly, my hair is growing back. The weird thing is, it is growing back curly. My hair has been straight my entire life. But since I lost a bunch, it is coming in curly. The hair that did not fall out is still stick straight, its just the regrowth that is curly. At first I thought it was just because it was short. But it is now about 2.5ish inches long and is still quite curly. I am not upset by this, just quite amused. I have no idea why it is doing this, or if it will even stay like this. I was just wondering if anyone has experienced something similar.
Thanks.
column9: Dear breeszewcgnb54, we would like to inform you that we edited your post to remove the link you have posted. As per our community guidelines, outside links are not allowed on the forums. Thanks for your understanding!

column5:
So my appointment was horrible.  There was a femme in the room with me at the appointment,  but I still had major flashbacks of not only what my dad did, but what every other person who attacked me has done...over 3 decades of various assaults.
  Last night I had major nightmares of the things that have been done to me.   My recovery has been suffering as a result.

column5: So my grandpa is getting released from the hospital this evening. And my mom told me we’re going out of town tomorrow and coming back Tuesday. I’m overwhelmed and stressed because this was so sudden and have strong urges to exercise again. I’m gonna watch tv to distract myself instead. I just struggle with traveling in general and traveling with my parents during a stressful time is overwhelming. Then my grandpa has to go back to the burn center Friday for more procedures because his burns were so deep on his face. I’m afraid to see him like that. I know it’s a selfish and horrible thing to think. I don’t want to watch him suffer. But I will do anything for him and if it makes him happy to see me I will do it with a smile on my face. I’m trying to think of things to pack to help me stay grounded and distracted / cope but I’m blanking. Any ideas?

column4: Will I ever go back to my pre-ED weight?
column5: Hi all; I'll try to keep this concise.I used to weigh a pretty normal weight, 18 years old, but i was a little flabby, so I wanted to lose weight.Last January, about 1 1/2 years ago, I developed an eating disorder. Lost my period really damn quickly. I restricted to no more than a low amount of calories a day, and that went on for about five months; I got to my lowest weight this way. After that I was sick of eating so little, so I reverse-dieted to eating around my maintenance calories a day. However, I still gained weight (some of it muscle, but definitely a lot of fat too) and from both higher calories and weeky/monthly binges, I found my way back to my original weight without really even recovering.I'm restored to my original weight, but I still have no period, and I was restricting, exercising, but gaining weight on low calories. Thats called Quasi-recovery, I guess.Anyways, three days ago I finally decided to put my foot down and recover for REAL this time. I've been eating what I want when I want, and I think I've been eating around X calories per day, by my estimation (I stopped counting).However, my question is this: since I started to really recover when I was ALREADY at my original weight, will I ever get back to my pre-ED weight? Or after I have fully recovered, will I always be at my new higher weight? I've never been above my original weight in my life, but now I will be. I've heard about set-point theory and a lot of internet sources say that recovered anorexics "will eventually go back to their pre-ED weight," but I don't know if that applies to me, since I've gained all the weight back but still need to actually recover. I've only read about recovery for people starting real recovery when underweight.If anyone has a story like mine, or knows how my particular case might play out, I'd love to hear. Please.(I want to disclaim that regardless of how much I will weigh at the end of my recovery, I'm going to accept it.  I don't ever want to try weight loss again.  I'm just curious to know if I will stay at my higher weight.)

They say it’s very bad for me to do and I guess deep down I kind of know that’s true. But I can’t just let go of something I’ve been doing for years. I want to either purge or self harm. I don’t know how to get rid of the urge. Does anyone know a good way to distract myself?

column5:
I'm losing this fight right now. I've lost a lot of weight. And I just want to go further. I feel tired and sick but the voice in my head says im not sick enough cuz I only have "atypical" anorexia right now which my eating disorder tells me isn't the "real thing" and I can't get help until its real.
Also things are stressful, my marriage isn't doing well and we're moving to a new apartment and I think I might be pregnant. Seriously, this is all just way too much.

column5: This is my first time writing something like this, so please excuse me if i make any mistake (side not; english is not my native language). Everything started when my classmates (2nd grade, high school) praised me about how skinny i am and how good it is. So i naturally started to think my qualify is being skinny and nothing else. I was around X weight these times and my height was X. I never dieted in my life before until the summer after 2nd grade. I thought i should look skinnier because i will gain weight once school starts again. And my weight dropped. After school started, everything was fine until winter arrived. I saw 46 kg on the scale and couldnt believe my eyes. So i started dieting again and at the same time i was trying to exercise at home. (I couldnt exercise in the gym because my family would never allow me to do, saying you are already skinny enough.) I fasted for a month in summer and i was back to X weight again. But there was a problem. My university exam year was coming and i had to focus my lessons only. I tried to not think about what i eat or how much i eat. (my goal was medical university -thankfully i am in medical university rn- so i had to study so much, and since brain needs glucose to work i had to eat normally) I weighed X on 4th grade. But i was telling myself, once this year is over you will be X weight again. But i could only reach X kg that summer. I went to another city for university. I am staying at the dorm, we dont have a scale here (tbh i wouldnt scale myself even if there was a scale cause im too scared). I came to my hometown for winter break. Scaled myself with lots of anxiety and fear. I weighed X kg which is totally shocking. Because i thought i would gain weight there. I thought i ate more food compared to summer. And now im leaving my hometown again because my break is over. My weight is X kg. I never weighed that much in my life before. I feel bloated. It feels like im carrying fat barrels on my thighs. My thigh gap looks smaller when i look in the mirror. This situation is freaking me out because i didnt even eat too much food. I even lost my period, i have anemia, im freezing all the time so i dont wanna go any further. But at the same time i wanna restrict. Because it looks like the only way for me to loose weight. I hate throwing up and i never throw up i have strong stomach. Im thinking about binging and purging. Im also scared of doctors, dietitians... But you know why? Im hella anxious about showing my body to someone else. I was having such a bad moment atm and burst in tears when i looked in the mirror. But writing these sentences relieved me a little bit. I know this is too long and i feel like people are gonna judge me saying "you dont even have an eating disorder you are just craving for attention" but i swear to god this is not the case. I have an unhealthy relationship with food and i wanna fix that so bad. (I tried to talk about my disorder with my family or friends but they are only forcing me to eat more food. I dont think they take eating disorders serious.)

column4: I don’t know what to eat
column5: Hi, I’ve been relapsing and recovering from an eating disorder for about a year now. Although I’m a healthy weight and even towards the right hand side of the ideal BMI, I have continued to restrict for the past year to about X calories. Although to everyone else I look like I’ve recovered I have still been religiously monitoring and restricting calories. My body is now used to maintaining its weight at X calories. Now I have taken action and decided to properly recover I am ALWAYS hungry and never satiated no matter how much I eat. However I know if I binge I’ll gain too fast and relapse properly so I am maintaining my daily recommended intake but I am putting on loads of weight from doing so. I feel like I have ruined my metabolism forever. No matter how much I want to recover it seems my body won’t let me. is there any way I can fix my metabolism? I also no longer know what is normal. I don’t know what time people eat or how much or whether they feel full? Should I still be tracking calories? Any advice would be welcomed. Thanks :)

column4: My eating disorder is self care?
column5:
I have graduated out of my treatment center for almost a year now and it has been a constant struggle between recover and my eating disorder ever since. My eating disorder can sound so sneaky and logical sometimes. I have intense anxiety all the time and especially with school having started back up, my stomach is in constant knots. In treatment, I have heard that I need to trust my body, listen to what it is trying to tell me. And at the same time, don't listen to it because it is wrong and even when I feel sick to my stomach, I must eat. It is a very hard balance. And The acid reflux just compounds the struggle to eat.
So my eating disorder tells me not to eat because I'm just listening to my body and to eat would be a betrayal against my body. To eat would be a violation. I guess I also have connected my trauma to the act of eating as well. So in my disordered brain, I think I am taking care of myself by not eating. Even though I know to eat is to nurture. To eat is to care for myself, to fight against the trauma. It's all so confusing.
So I guess I'm wondering, does anyone know how to balance these two sides? How to eat despite the fact that my body seems to be screaming "NO"? Is it about forcing? I feel myself slipping backwards quickly now and it scares me. Eating disorders can be so lonely so if anyone can relate, to hear from you would be appreciated.
column9: Dear msatomicbomb, we would like to inform you that we edited your post to remove some language about trauma that could be triggering to other users. You can review our community guidelines here. Thanks for your understanding and please continue to post!

column5: Sharing my story in the hopes someone else out there has gone through a similar journey and can give me some hope.Also lots of these posts I see are from girls in high school or university. I am in my mid-twenties and dealing with this. In some ways I wish this happened to me when I was younger.. I would be living a better life already, at least that's what I think.I'll tell you my story: When I finished uni, I got into running. At first it was just a fun hobby to feel good.. but then I became very very good. I reached an elite level. As a result, I started taking pride in my nutrition. I became an extremely healthy eater.. which then led to me deciding to become a plant-based athlete, and I cut out all animal products, meat, etc. As my times continued to drop, so did my weight. I was getting so many compliments from people noticing how fit and fast I was. Then I got a bone injury.. my first ever. During this time I was even more rigid about my eating.. 8 weeks of pool running later, I was back running and no setbacks. Funny how history can repeat itself.. a year later.. I got my second bone injury (Feb 2019).This time I did not cope well. I spent 3 months relentlessly pool running, waiting for the bone to heal.. and when it finally did, my mental health was not in a good place. I suddenly became so insecure I thought I had put on so much weight ( I didn't but in my mind I thought I did)... started hiding from friends, training partners, etc. as I didn't want anyone to see me.. this is when the binging episodes started. I felt lost and alone in this struggle to put myself back out there, but by isolating myself and "waiting to lose weight.. I just ended up gaining MORE weight.I didn't want to tell anyone what was going on.. so after 3 months of dealing with binging.. which at the time was very small episodes.. I called my parents and told them everything. Immediately they told me to come home and they'd help me. BIG MISTAKE. I gave up my life and then had to swallow my pride and live with my parents. I became even more depressed and for 2 months with them, I became even more out of control with my eating. Some days I felt suicidal.Finally I got out of their house, moved cities and have since reached out to sports psychiatrist, sport doctor, ED dietician, counsellor etc. 6 months later, the binges are less, but I have had the hardest time getting back to my  passion: running. I have had injury after injury. I think when i was in a state of energy deficiency for so long, my muscles, bones, soft tissue were weakened.Now: I am bigger than I ever have been! I mean I look like a strong athlete, but not like the lean, toned, slim runner I used to be. It's shocking!!! Each day I am trying to be kinder to self, and accept the new person I am. Its incredibly difficult and I wonder if I'll ever get back to my old self, the girl I used to be before the ED took hold of me. I  also must mention my body went through hell. When I first started gaining weight from binging it all went straight to my stomach.. over time it has distributed.

column4: Nausea, Extreme hunger, and chills...am I okay?
column5:
Hello! After going back and forth for 5 years with my eating disorder I'm seeking professional help. I've been trying to self-recover but I don't think I'm getting enough calories. Yesterday I thought I ate enough but I couldn't even sleep last night because I was hungry. I got up at 2am to try to eat something but everything was so unappetizing to me so I was basically forcing food down. This morning was no different when I was eating breakfast everything on my plate didn't taste appetizing. Even the thought of food/looking at it makes me feel nauseous which scares me because I'm trying to recover and feel normal.This morning I felt nauseous after eating. The thought of food made me feel sick. All I want to eat is certain foods. Dreading lunch where I know I'll have to eat another thing and feel sick eating it. Lunch was similar in that I was forcing down food because I knew I needed calories, but I felt nauseous at the thought of food. I could not take down much. At this point, my nausea from everything slowing shifting into my "extreme hunger" phase. This wasn't the first time I experienced extreme hunger, and both times although I was somewhat starving, I wasn't open to eating all types of food and some foods made me nauseous/sick even though I was hungry.
told my parents and they got me a meal. While I was waiting for the food from the store, I made myself a snack so I could have something. I drank half before I got light headed ans got chills and needed to be under 2 comforters. While in bed, the meal was brought to me and I tried to eat it. After a bite I couldn't keep it down and felt like I was going to throw up. Please tell me this is normal because I'm scared and I want this to be over and I want to feel well.

It didn't help I woke up at 5:30 this morning.   My depression is weighing on me like a blanket made out of cinder blocks..

Please take good care of yourself, and please continue posting. We hope things get better soon.

column5: Hi, I struggle with swings from anorexia to compulsive overeating, or just generally abusing my body with food. For the last five years, I have been eating only fast food and non-nutritional food. At the beginning of January, I decided I wanted to get healthier. I eliminated some types of foods. I did decide to have one day a week that I can maybe eat a dessert or restaurant food, so that I can maintain balance and not start practicing my anorexia again. My husband was on training for three weeks and just got home Friday night. Last night, he said that he wanted to order delivery. I suggested delivery from a healthier option he only wanted X food. I wanted it to be enjoyable and not have to order from two different places, which wouldn’t come at the same time, so I caved and order two very unhealthy options. I immediately felt pain in my stomach and had indigestion. I brought it up to him, explaining that I am not strong enough to say no, and he shouldn’t have brought up ordering out, then also forcing me to order from that place. He said he should be allowed to have X food whenever he wants, and what is the compromise, I said that I was out 5 hours during the day, he could have eaten the X food when I wasn’t home. He said, “but I wanted it for supper”. It turned into a huge argument and he still says that his opinion is he can eat X food whenever he wants. He doesn’t get it and I don’t know what to do. I have an addictive personality and one mistake can turn back into 5 years of abuse to myself. This was his first day back from training and I feel like he could have been more supportive, he disagrees. We are now at a standstill and I don’t know how to resolve it. I am so hurt and disappointed with his reaction. I feel like he is being really selfish and putting a desire for X food above my health. I agree he should be allowed to eat X food whenever, but a) perhaps he could have waited until I was further along in my progress not his first day back b) I think he should eat it, but not suggest ordering it to me. While he was gone, I did a really good job at working on cravings and making good choices. I did express my fear of him returning and me sliding back into unhealthy choices, so I have expressed my needs prior to this happening. Any advice?
column9: Dear kalicomes, we would like to inform you that we edited portions of your post to remove mentions of specific foods that could be triggering to other users. You can review our community guidelines here. Thanks for your understanding and please continue to post!

column5:
Hi all!I'm really struggling with the refeeding process while living at home. My hunger is insatiable; I can never get full, and it's mortifying. I'm so hungry, but I'm so embarrassed by how much I'm eating/want to eat around my family, who all work from home. They know I had anorexia, but I don't think they realize that I'm STILL recovering and that I need more food/nutrition (I didn't realize this until about two weeks ago, myself, when I finally acknowledged how hungry I was and that I was still restricting even though I thought I had finally achieved my ideal body weight. Since, I have let go of that feeling of an "ideal body weight" and am just trying to get better so I can live my life). So regarding my embarrassment at home and around my family--what can I do? How can I make them believe me now when in the past I've been so wrong about food? Xoxo, thetimetoliveisnowP.S.
A bit about me: I'm 22 years old and taking a year off from college. I'm working and traveling for pleasure, intermittently. I've been suffering from AN for the past 3.5 years and am trying to recover.

How is the depression?  Are you feeling any more motivated?  I want you to know that I am here for you, anytime.  And thank you.iwanttolive

column5: I was first diagnosed with an eating disorder 20 years ago when I was 12, then I was hospitalized for several months when I was 18 and spent several years in therapy with an eating disorder specialist. I learned a lot and gained a whole toolbox full of coping mechanisms and for over a decade I've been dealing with it on my own. That little voice is always, always there, but I've gotten really good at telling it to shut up. Sometimes though, I still have like these flare ups, like suddenly falling back into it and giving in to the voice telling me "don't". But i was always able to get back to a healthy lifestyle again, even though the voice never goes away. But I've always been ob my own so it never affected anyone except me. I've been stuck in one of these flare ups for about a month, but now i have a family and what I'm going through affects way more than just me. I know there's no quick fix or easy solution,  trust me I know this, but if anyone has any advice about how to get myself back on track this time? I'm not even really sure what I'm looking for, I just wanted to talk to people who understand. Thanks, all.

column5: Hi everyone!I was wondering if anyone else has had a similar experience or if this is uncommon. I've been doing research but haven't found much info. Prior to going into intensive treatment for anorexia after struggling for 10 years, I used to love "highly nutritious foods" - usually plain - I loved it. Since coming out of recovery and doing very well, I find I actually get turned off of foods like this. My mom gets so frustrated now every time she makes a nice meal for me that is on the more nutritious side because I legitimately struggle to get it down. Not because I'm afraid of it just because it actually grosses me out! I genuinely would find it easier now to throw back some fast food than a more nutritious cooked meal (which is totally against how my ED voice would have been before).Is this normal? Has anyone else experienced this? I'm trying hard because obviously I know I need to have a well rounded diet but lately it has been a struggle!Thanks in advance :)

column5: I am currently in the stages of recovery and am seeking professional help.  I am so pleased with my progress with food and am sticking to my regular eating plan - I haven't purged or binged for over 2 months now.  I am in a new relationship and feel so content, but I am really really struggling.  I can't control or regulate my emotions - one minute I am on a manic high, and the next I am so low I can't even move.  I seek other ways to punish myself, like hurting myself.  I just need reassuring that this is just the road to recovery and I am not completely bonkers.  I just want to be happy and proud of my recovery, but at the moment my mood just seems to be getting the better of me. I don't want this to affect my relationship.

column5: Hello everyone,I've never posted on a forum before so I'm a little bit scared but basically.I am 26 and when I was 15 I suffered with Anorexia for a few years and then it has been off and on since then but never as bad as I was when I was younger.However, in the past 2 years, I started to binge and purge to control my weight and I was going through a bad time with my boyfriend and I think that made me do it as well.  I'm really active and enjoy sports and eating healthy but I can't seem to stop the binge and purge cycle.  I have a great job, circle or friends and life at the moment so it seems to be getting in the way.  About a year ago, my periods stopped and I'm now worrying that it will affect my chances to have children.  The doctors said I have a low heart beat and I am sometimes out of breath easily and experiencing heart burn.  I can go weeks with out a binge and purging but then as if out of nowhere (normally when I'm home alone) I do it again and can be doing it every day.  I told my boyfriend but he doesn't really understand and sometimes, my mood swings are crazy and I don't know if this is related. Sometimes, I just wish I had someone to talk to who understands what I'm going through.  Anyway, I just wanted to know if anyone had any tips how to stop the binge? What techniques do you all use that you find helpful ad work for you?Thank you for reading.

column4: "Don't worry about junk food eating in recovery"... for how long? When does it stop?
column5:
My disordered eating started age 7, full blown anorexia at age 15, and i started recovering age 19-20. I'm now 26.
For me, I kind of recovered backwards... my psychological recovery happened first and I rarely if ever struggle with it anymore. However my physical and behavioral recovery I am struggling with.
Ive searched the internet and the only things I can find regarding sugar in recovery are people saying not to worry about it or encouraging it. Saying to eat whatever you crave. And that's what I started off doing but it's been years now and it only seems to be getting worse.
My intuitive eating tells me to eat any hour of the day and it ends up being all over the place. And it tells me to eat pretty much pure sugar.  And because of that I never have the chance to think about fruits and vegetables. It makes my body feel so unhealthy and my family is getting concerned but I've been telling them "no, in recovery you have to eat whatever and whenever your body wants you to because you need to take advantage of that appetite and learn to follow your cravings!" But it's been years now and they're starting to say that's wrong. I'm starting to doubt it too but now I'm so addicted to sugar.Also, I thought eating sugar and junk food would help me put on weight fast?? But Im still very severely underweight! I don't understand. My dad is a fitness instructor and he says I need to eat healthy food to gain weight but this goes against everything I've ever known... don't people always call sugary stuff "fattening"? And they eat healthy to lose weight? So I don't understand?I'm really tired of eating so unhealthy and it's honestly sapping my energy and ruining my teeth by now. What should I do?
column9: Dear jasmyn, we would like to inform you that we edited your post to remove mentions of specific food items which could be triggering to others. You can review our community guidelines here. Also please know that the NEDA Helpline is always an option to get support and resources. It can be reached at 800.931.2237 or chat with them online (http://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/helplinechat) M-TH 9-9 EST and F 9-5 EST. Thanks for your understanding and please continue to post!

column5: So as some of you know, I have been having some trials with my therapist.  Today went very well.  She said the term "feeling sorry for myself" was and is not a judgement.  She said she was feeling sorry for herself because she hurt her back last night.  We reworded it to make it more palatable to me.  That things were very difficult.  I have this picture of my one sister who was incredibly able to attend Christmas dinner even thought she can't eat, and when pictures were taken my one sister/friend and my sister were standing very close, my sister leaning into my friend with me standing alone.  Tonight I went out to eat with my sister visiting from North Carolina and her son along with my parents.  As we got seated, two of us, my sister and myself, were sitting next to each other on one bench, and her son on another between us and my parents.  But then she moved and left me sitting alone on the bench and it really hurt.   I frequently get dismissed in conversation and mid sentence.  I showed my therapist the picture taken of us at Christmas and she clearly sees the rejection and alienation from my sisters.  My parents are unable to see it.  Even tonight.  I like to clear the table and move the plates to the edges of the table to make it easier for the server.  My father hates this but I said I want to do it.  He allowed me to for the first time.  But my sister who was farthest from the end of the table refused to allow me to put her dishes with the rest at the end of the table.  Such ridiculous things but hurtful and sends me the message of "I matter, you don't" to me and that I am not important and stupid.  She has always been superior and taken away my baby sitting jobs and got close to the people I was close to including her current husband.  We were friends and were trying to start up a group at church for those in their 20"s and 30'.  She somehow caught wind of it and before you know it she left school in North Carolina and they were married not too long after.My Mom's friend really understands me and believes me about the pain I experience with this rejection.As for my therapist, she believes I do suffer from a serious level of PTSD and not so much Borderline.  I know I don't have Borderline, but know my symptoms correlate with PTSD.  She agreed but does not feel this is the time to work in force with the PTSD until I am more stable and we know how my sister will do.  She is not doing well.  Had a fever of 104.5 today and she never gets fevers because of her dysautonomia.  She has a blood infection and the port where she is fed is infected and needs to come out.  TPN feeding, done through a port, is dangerous and life threatening and not meant for long term use as it can cause death.  The doctor believes she isn't tolerating the TPN and will give her  nutrition through a vein but she has none so we don't know how this is going to work.  Then they will put her port on the other side of her neck once the infection is cleared.My therapist still does not want me going to my house until we figure out what is happening with my sister.  She is still very aggressive with me as sick as she is.  But I am not listened to and ignored and unimportant.  There comes the overeating and thoughts of self harm because I just don't know how to deal with all of this.My therapist if finally going to try to work on seeing me twice a week.  I tried the support group she recommended and pulled out some DBT skills so she knows I am trying and listening to herp advice.  I have been with her for about two and a half years and really don't want to start new with someone who doesn't know me at all or my parents.  I will start going to a support group that is Christ centered.  This coming Monday.  It meets weekly so that is positive.There is so much going on it is difficult to keep this short.  I apologize.  I am going to bed early tonight.  I am so tired and worked four days this week.  I usually work three.  Four is a lot plus going to the hospital and visiting with my sister and all that.  I wish you all well.  You are all terrific even as we battle life's complications.  We support each other and do our best.  And when we can't do our best, we wait until we can again and then start from there.  Hugs to everyone.iwanttolive

At the end of the day I'm still correcting (with the help and threatening of my dietitian). It feels like I'll never get out, never be free, yet at the same time I'm a little afraid of freedom. Hope that makes sense.

column5: It’s becoming increasingly difficult for me to maintain recovery. I had graduated from a recovery center in September, and for a little while I was doing pretty well. But now my intrusive thoughts are getting a lot worse. I can’t stop thinking about how I look and what I’m eating. I feel like the ugliest person in the world, I’m terrified to leave my house because people will see me and judge me. I obsessively look in the mirror and take pictures of myself hoping one of them will look good enough. Dressing up has always been one of my biggest passions, but now I’m scared to wear certain things because I get scared people will judge me and my body for how I look in them. I’m still eating regularly for the most part, but I’m going back to disordered habits. The negative thoughts and emotions are so overwhelming. I was determined to recover before, I’ve always wanted to be an activist for eating disorder awareness and body positivity and I wanted to recover so I can achieve my career goals, but I also want people to love me and think that I’m attractive. Now, I don’t know if I want to recover, and it’s hard to tell if it’s the right thing when everywhere I look I see new diets and people praising others for being conventionally attractive while putting others down for not looking a certain way. I think one thing that caused things to go wrong was that after graduating I was supposed to have a therapist and a dietitian to see regularly. I do have a therapist I see every 2 weeks, but I never got a dietitian since my family and I got distracted by other things. I want to bring it up, but my parents always say how expensive I am already, so I feel too guilty. It’s also hard not having a support system like I did at the center, where I could talk to other people struggling with eating disorders and people trained specifically for eating disorders. I’m starting college in a couple weeks and I’m terrified I’ll fail because my mind is so preoccupied with food and how I look, and that other people will judge me for how I look. I’m sorry this is so long, I just don’t know what to do.

column5: Some say these behaviors are a way to communicate the pain we can’t seem to find the words to articulate, the magnitude of suffering . However, I don’t always agree with this theory . I can clearly articulate the pain and frustration I’m feeling yet the emotion is so intense I need more to feel like it’s moving from the deep part of my soul. I’m beyond angry.... not only with myself but with individuals who claim they love me ... I call bullshit . At this point I want to purge and self harm I need to escape this misery and numb the pain that’s causing me to be very emotional, tearful. I don’t know what to do anymore I’m so lost .

 Also know that the NEDA Helpline can be reached at 800.931.2237 or chat with them online (http://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/helplinechat) M-TH 9-9 EST and F 9-5 EST. You are not alone. Please take care of yourself.

column5:
A while ago I looked at my body and my diet and was disappointed. I had a ton of snacks everyday and ate a lot. And my body showed it. I wasn't obese, just overweight. I decided to start exercising and eat better. It started okay, but then I started counting calories and became obsessive. I soon figured that the less calories the better. I lost a significant amount of weight. (my family became very concerned.) I went off my diet, but i was almost underweight now. I now have an all messed up relationship with food. I obsess with when and what i'll eat. (it's all I think about.) And I'm a little scared to eat around others. And sometimes I eat way too much, or way too little. I've only binged and purged twice, but I still don't think I have an eating disorder.
I mean i'm here, but while I still obsess over food and am almost underweight, I haven't been dealing with it that long. Can I even say that I have an eating disorder? I feel like if I say I have an eating disorder it will disregard others that have been dealing with it for years and have been hospitalized. I just don't know...

column5:
I feel like a worthless pile of garbage.
I was grinding my teeth in my sleep last night and partially bit one of my brackets from my braces off. I called and go in next Tuesday to have it fixed as I already had an appointment that day anyway.
This tiny thing that didn’t turn into a big problem caused me to spiral. Like I feel like I’m not equipped to handle life when I get so stressed and overwhelmed that I shut down over something so small. I feel defective.
I have to be careful about what I eat until the bracket is fixed, yet that’s still not enough to deter me from planning a binge when my mom goes out later and I’ll be home alone. I want to binge so badly I can’t stand it. What is wrong with me???? Why am I like this??? You hear all these things about how going through traumatic things and having a traumatic childhood makes you strong and resilient but it doesn’t feel that way for me at all, it feels like the opposite. Like I am so full of ptsd stress all the time, even subconsciously, that a tiny external stressor causes me to shut down.

column5: I am really struggling and it doesn't help when my Mom tells me that it is not acceptable that I "binge" in her house.  First of all I am not binging but overeating.  I eat in my room in her house.  She is telling me I am not to have food in my  room anymore.  I am trying to see my therapist twice a week but she is so busy she doesn't have and hasn't had any openings.  My mom asked me if I had anyone I could talk with outside of therapy and I said no.  She said no one?  It makes me sad to feel so alone.  To want a hug not a lecture from my parents.  I know they love me.  I just want it expressed in different ways.  Hugs.   A back rub if I ask for one.  To have them listen to a five minute testimony I did at church a few weeks ago but after I asked three times and the timing was never right, I stopped asking.  It won't ever be listened to.My dad can spend five hours with someone form church helping them get ready for court where he will be with them tomorrow.  But to have him help me finish the complaint from when I was in the hospital, it is asking too much and they don't have the time.AND I really offended someone from church and she sent a rather scathing text some places in bold saying to NEVER drop by their home, EVER and to respect her BOUNDARIES.  I dropped off two pictures I colored since they weren't in church Sunday, parking my car several houses down and left the pictures on their porch, and left without knocking or calling.  BUT it was an huge violation of her and I feel so terrible and so ugly and so down on myself for upsetting her so much.  I  got lost for forty minutes or so after tryin to get my dog to her appointment for grooming.  She looks really good and as of Thursday she will be my emotional support dog.  I am sorry to go on and on lately.  I know you all  are dealing with major difficulties and I am just a pain, I know.  I am sorry.  I just need to be heard.   I am not heard at home.  I want to sleep for days but I can't.  I wake up at 7am every day, without fail.  So for now, and again I apologize for the negative frame of mind I have been in.  I just want it all to stop.  But it won't and I am with my parents and they fight but if I do it isn't allowed.  On and on it goes.

column4: Feeling triggered after years in recovery
column5:
Hi everyone,
I'm reaching out because I had a bad experience recently which has triggered unhealthy thoughts and I'm a bit lost as to what to do, especially as I considered myself pretty much fully recovered and am quite shaken by how much this has gotten to me.
Brief background: I had anorexia from the age of 11 and was particularly bad and hospitalised ages 15-17. I'm 22 now and have been doing really well for about 3 years, so much so that I wouldn't consider myself to have an ED anymore and rarely think about it.
It sounds really stupid what's triggered this but here goes. Essentially, I'm going to a festival next year and bought some new clothes for it, lots of which are quite skimpy, cropped tops etc. I tried them on last night and, although I wasn't in a particularly bad place in my head, suddenly got really paranoid that I looked stupid. It's incredibly frustrating because first of all I'm always preaching to my friends about body positivity - I think people should wear whatever they're comfortable in and rock it their own way. Sadly, though, I don't apply the same standards to myself. Secondly, I know, factually, I have a healthy BMI and have been fairly comfortable with my weight for a while now. I do however, obviously, weigh more than I did when I was really ill, and although I *know* that's a good thing, my thoughts are conveying that it’s unattractive.
I haven't had thoughts like this, at least not this compulsively and self-critically, for a long time and I feel awful. After I took the clothes off I cried and cried then felt the need to revert to my ED behaviors. For example, I skipped dinner, which I told myself was because I felt sick but I kind of know I didn't want to eat because I'd feel guilty about it.
I know everybody gets self-conscious but I'm worried because of how much it's hurting me and the thoughts I'm having around it. It's really taken me by surprise as I've had a relatively healthy relationship with my weight, food and exercise for a few years now and it's so out of the blue and really intense really suddenly.
I don't know what to do or who to turn to - I don't see a therapist or any mental health professionals anymore and I don't want to mention it to my friends in case they worry I'm getting ill again. I feel like it might just be a blip and maybe in a couple of days I'll get over it/feel better about it, but considering my experience and how rapidly I know things can spiral out of control I don't know what I can do to keep myself healthy and on track. I might be overreacting, I don't know, it's just really painful to be having these thoughts and compulsions again when I thought I was doing so good.
Sorry for such a long post and thanks a million if you read it all, any advice or supportive words would be appreciated, I just needed to vent about it somewhere I felt I wouldn't be judged

column5: So I love weight training- it empowers me and helps my anxiety. I don’t obsessively do it like I did with cardio when my ed was in complete control. I know I mentioned in another thread that I was having issues with my cycle. Well it was because I didn’t ovulate, so when I did get my period it was drug out and heavy. I started feeling really weak and dizzy. I worked out two days during and it did me in. I honestly thought it would be ok- sometimes it is still hard for to take a rest day, but thankfully I have my husband to tell me what is rational. He made me realize that my body was going through so much, and I didn’t need to add the extra stress of a workout on top of it. My body feels much better for it. The whole experience just made me realize I still need someone to point out to me when I’m doing too much. I need to slow down.
column9: Hi Lizzbanton 15! You mentioned some concerning symptoms in your post for which you may want to seek medical attention. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention: •accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury •become suicidal •confused thinking and is not making any sense •delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there) •disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are •vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea •experiencing dizziness or fainting spells •too weak to walk or collapses •painful muscle spasms •complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing •blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit •a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16 •an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute) •cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees Fahrenheit. If you experience any of the above, we highly recommend that you seek medical attention as soon as possible. Another option is 911. Seek medical help soon on an outpatient basis if you: •have significant heartburn and/or a burning sensation after eating •have other gastrointestinal concerns •have high blood pressure •struggle with significant joint or muscle pain •have difficulty sleeping (falling and/or remaining asleep) •struggle with fatigue, sudden weight gain, and/or hair loss •have frequent urination or unquenchable thirst •have gained and lost significant weight repeatedly •have gained significant weight in a short period of time •struggle with chronic diarrhea or constipation. Please do not hesitate to call the NEDA helpline at 1-800-931-2237 (Monday-Thursday 9:00am-9:00pm, Friday 9:00am-5:00pm EST) if you need help finding resources and support. Please take care.

column5:
So today in class I heard a dialogue between two boys that were just talking across the room. They were talking all jokingly, but it was still weird..
1.Is it bad that I can't gain weight from eating absolute junk? Because of my fast metabolism.
2. bad? I think you mean lucky! I gain weight even from eating healthy!And another girl at my lunch table is always saying something along these lines, "I'm small and skinny! I don't gain weight. (name) says i'm gonna get diabetes!"I don't know it's just a little triggering... At lunch I have a problem of comparing myself to what others eat. Sometimes they eat less and sometimes more than me. It's like i'm the only one actually thinking about food the whole time. Anyone else relate to feeling like your the only one with food on your mind?
column9: Hi! We edited some of the language in this thread to remove mentions of specific food items, which are not allowed on the forums. The community guidelines can be reviewed here. Thanks you for understanding and please continue to post!

column5:
I just went out to dinner with my mom and she made made a somewhat... triggering comment. Some backstory... I have some anorexic tendencies, but have not been diagnosed. And my mom thinks I have it, anyway she has cried and given me self help books and is just generally concerned about me being underweight. So she knows that me and food are complicated.
Back to the story, I have actually been trying to gain weight so I kept this in mind when we went out to eat. I ordered some food. The sandwich was large, but it wasn't gargantuan. I ate the whole thing and when I finished she said, "Wow, I didn't expect you to eat that whole thing. I thought you would take half of it home."
I replied, "Was it really that big?" I felt very self-conscious at this point.
And then she said, "Kinda, I mean it was A LOT of food."
I said, "Well... I don't know, it was a large meal..."
And right after that I feel like restricting. Why would she say that when she knows? I feel like a fat mess. I want to skip meals but I know the responsible thing to do is to not skip... I feel so frustrated. I was a big sandwich okay! But I ate it! I feel so horrible.
column8: Dear Miggi, we would like to
column9: Dear Miggi, we would like to inform you that we edited your post to remove specifics about food items, which could be triggering to other users. You can review our community guidelines here. Thanks for your understanding and please continue to post!

column4: I still want to lose weight
column5: Hello- I've been in recovery for over a year now. I see a therapist and a dietician for binge eating and restricting. When I first started I was in a diet program and lost a lot of weight. I have now gained all that back and then some while in recovery. I've been struggling with wanting to lose weight, even though I have been in recovery and agreeing with anti-diet and health at every size philosophy. I feel a lot of guilt about it. I don't really know what to do. I wish my motivation for exercise was to feel good in the body instead of trying to lose weight. I wish I still didn't idolize thinner bodies even though I know logically that I'm fine where I am and I don't have to be thin to be healthy and beautiful. It really sucks to feel like I'm still wanting to be small. Does anyone out there who lives in a bigger body feel this way? How do you love yourself through this process?
column9: Dear NRecovery89, we would like to inform you that we edited your post to remove the name of the diet program, which could be triggering to other users. You can review our community guidelines here. Thanks for your understanding and please continue to post!

column5: I’m feeling insecure in my body. I thought I was past so much, but I’m not and I don’t know how to deal with that. I’m terrified. I’m really struggling with body image and body dysmorphia. I don’t see how I could ever fully accept my body. I focus on the part I hate everyday now.

column5: Hi I am new here.  I had a horrible thanksgiving.  Nobody invited me.  Both of my brothers bragged about who and what they were going to do and even invited each other but not me. My husband and I had a lovely dinner. Then, things started to get worse. I had urges to self-harm. Friday and Saturdays were better.  I was sewing with friends. Today I decided I would do something.  I called a friend and told her and an on line friend everything.  I made a promise I would call my psychiatrist and therapist tomorrow. I will do that.
column9:
Hi Mrssirpatrick – welcome to the forums. We’re so sorry to hear you are struggling with difficult feelings right now. Since you mentioned some concerning feelings, we wanted to make sure you have access to resources if you need to reach out for support. 
 You are not alone. Please find support, continue posting and take care.

column4: Feeling painfully full on meal plan
column5: so I have just begun recovery (diagnosed by a specialist literally 4 days ago) and my parents have jumped right in with a full meal plan, they choose everything and i have to finish everything. however recently after a big lunch i feel ok, but then the snack is usually just as big and halfway through I feel full. then uncomfortably, then painfully full and although my body (or maybe the ED) is feeling sick and sore and bloated my parents say i have to suck it up (in a nicer way) and get through it. it sucks because i end up hating the food i just had that made me feel so sick. i struggle after the meals seeing myself so bloated and knowing it's going to happen all over again, and begin to dread the next meal knowing even if i feel full or sick i won't be able to take a break. i hate myself after this and sometimes it ruins a meal i was proud of eating-and turns into disgust and fear and panic.is this normal? is it all in my head? thats what my parents keep telling me and serving the same or larger meals each time and shut me down mostly when i talk to them about what i feel like or eating or when i feel uncomfortable and sick. i feel bad for being 'picky' and yet terrified the only way to get through this ED is to eat until i feel sick and unhappy with myself, over and over-so every meal feels like a binge and yet one i can't avoid because it is being chosen for me.
column9: Hi CeeRecovery - welcome to the forums. We’re glad you’re here! Your post has been edited to comply with NEDA’s community guidelines (https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines). Number specifics are not allowed on the forums. Please take a moment to review the guidelines, and please continue posting.

column5:
Lately I have been feeling a lot of shame about eating and having as much on my meal plan as I do, because I’m in bed a lot and don’t have a lot of movement. Rationally my dietitian said I need this much to just survive, and I understand that, but emotionally it causes a lot of shame. I think I have been tying shame to food to avoid dealing with the underlying issues.
The tension between my parents right now is really affecting me. Having to comfort my mom as she sobbed the morning after my dad was hateful to her while she sat at his bedside in the ER, brought back a lot of bad memories. I got hurt standing up for her when I was young, still comforted her after, then was shamed by both of them for it. What a mind game. I’m really concerned my mom has a dissociative issue due to drastic changes in her personality, crying and scared to childlike and playful, to narcissistic almost. But she will never get counseling and it’s just sad to see. Luckily I personally have a dissociative disorder as well so it doesn’t freak me out, I’m just concerned. I know she’s endured a lot of trauma starting from when she was a small child to an adult and never has dealt with any of it.Today my depression was so heavy I felt like life was pointless and for the first time in a while, it was so difficult to eat. I didn’t meet my meal plan. I just didn’t care about anything, I especially don’t care about myself because I feel worthless so I think, why bother? I’m worth nothing to anyone. And I’ve been a horrible person because I ignore the people reaching out to me. I don’t know why I do this. Isolating is one thing but I never completely ignore everyone like this. Yet I can’t stop myself and it just makes me hate myself more because I’m a bad friend.
column9:
Hi tryingtobebrave. We’re so sorry to hear you’re struggling with these feelings right now. Since you mentioned some concerning feelings, we wanted to make sure you have access to resources if you need to reach out for support.
 You are not alone. Please continue posting and stay strong.

column5: I’m having a really bad day with depression. I feel really hopeless and everything is pointless. I feel like I’m useless and can’t handle life, like tiny things are so overwhelming. First, I had to reschedule an appointment at the holistic pain management clinic I go to because it’s snowing. But trying to figure out the next two weeks caused me to spiral. I can only handle going out two days at most. I finally figured things out but it was so stressful that I’m crashing now. I’m struggling with substance use cravings but luckily we don’t keep alcohol in the house and there’s nothing else either. So my next thought is to binge but that scares me so then I don’t want to eat at all. It’s overwhelming.

column4: Weight loss after eating disorder recovery
column5: I have been in recovery for approximately six months from binge eating disorder with the help of psychotherapy and an eating disorder nutritionist. Is it ever possible to lose weight (slowly over a long period of time) in recovery? My nutritionist says that I do not need to lose any, however, I feel differently. I've verbalized this with her. Since being in recovery I just feel more lethargic. I've definitely shifted my mindset and want to eat well and strength train. Is this something to push further during our next session?

You can take a look at our Community Guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines. Best wishes on your recovery and please continue posting.

column4: Is recovery from an eating disorder supposed to feel this "bad"?
column5: Hey everyone!I've been dealing with anorexia on and off for most of my adult life (I'm 23 years old). My first relapse was when I was around 19 years old. I quickly lost a lot over the course of four months. It wasn't until around Christmastime that year that I ended up paying for it and landed in the hospital after having a big holiday meal which triggered a Pancreatitis episode due to a severe amount of gallstones in my gallbladder thanks to my relapse. After having emergency surgery to remove my gallbladder, I healed over the course of a month and returned back to eating and gained everything back.Fast forward to now, I’ve once again been quickly losing weight over the course of several months, and I've finally hit rock bottom. I've lost my period, I'm cold all the time, and I'm absolutely done. After reaching this breaking point with my anorexia, I decided to finally choose recovery (currently self recovering at home while working with a therapist).That was three days ago.And now I’m just feeling really confused, lost, and a bit reluctant and would really love to hear from other people who recovered from eating disorders on what their experience was like when they first started, because for me? It’s been weird.The first day I decided to eat, I was ravenously hungry all day and I decided to follow through and honor it. Then, later that night, I woke up feeling severely dehydrated (my eyes and lips were literally dry as the sahara and I was so thirsty). On top of feeling really dehydrated, I had a really rapid heart rate and felt like I was going to pass out. I had to go pee and so I did and my urine was really really cloudy. Eventually, after drinking enough water and a sports electrolyte drink and taking a potassium and magnesium supplement with some food, I felt better and went to sleep.The second day, I woke up with absolutely no appetite. None whatsoever. Nada. Siltch. I was feeling really bloated and really full from the day before that I had no appetite at all. Despite having no appetite, I forced myself to eat and snack all day because despite feeling full, I was thinking about food constantly but know that my body is probably just really damaged from these past eight months of disordered eating. Throughout the second day, I felt so inexplicably tired, bloated, mentally foggy and drained. I had no mental energy, I couldn't think straight, and honestly just wanted to do absolutely nothing all day. I felt depressed and anxious.The third day (today), I feel exactly the same as the second day. I had absolutely no appetite, my body is now sore in weird places (like my back and my arms)?, my stomach is still bloated, I'm not hungry at all, my brain feels super foggy and tired and I feel absolutely useless. I've done legitimately nothing these past few days and I don't have the mental energy to do anything but lay around, eat, and sleep. I've eaten past fullness nearly every day (despite not feeling hungry or even craving anything) thinking it'd give me more energy, but now I just feel even more tired and more mentally foggy and just exhausted all the time.I don't have an appetite at all and feel extremely bloated and tired. I have headaches frequently and sometimes my heart beats faster than usual. I feel really sluggish and mentally foggy and overall depressed. Honestly, I have to force myself to eat sometimes because I legitimately have no appetite.Is this normal and will this get better? It's just a little disheartening when I finally want to get better and eat and my body's just fighting back.When will things go back to normal and I'll get my personality, my energy, and my life back?Does anyone have any advice from their eating disorder recovery? How did your body react at first when you began eating more?
column9: Hi chrysanthemym. Welcome to our forums! You mentioned some concerning symptoms in your post for which you may want to seek medical attention. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention: •accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury •become suicidal •confused thinking and is not making any sense •delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there) •disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are •vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea •experiencing dizziness or fainting spells •too weak to walk or collapses •painful muscle spasms •complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing •blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit •a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16 •an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute) •cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees Fahrenheit. If you experience any of the above, we highly recommend that you seek medical attention as soon as possible. Another option is 911. Seek medical help soon on an outpatient basis if you: •have significant heartburn and/or a burning sensation after eating •have other gastrointestinal concerns •have high blood pressure •struggle with significant joint or muscle pain •have difficulty sleeping (falling and/or remaining asleep) •struggle with fatigue, sudden weight gain, and/or hair loss •have frequent urination or unquenchable thirst •have gained and lost significant weight repeatedly •have gained significant weight in a short period of time •struggle with chronic diarrhea or constipation. Please take care of yourself.Your post also had to be edited due to the inclusion of numbers and weight specifics - you can take a look at our community guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines.

column5: As fall is ending and winter is coming it is getting colder. And others seem to be coping well, but not me. My nails are purple and sometimes I can't motivate myself to do anything because i'm too cold to do anything other than sit under a blanket. In years past I remember winter being cold yeah, but now it's like everything. I am CONSTANTLY aware of the temperatures of rooms. In school I will walk from class to class noting the warmest and coldest ones. I usually have to bundle up in sweaters just to give myself a fighting chance. Anyone else relate to this chill?
column9: Dear Miggi, thank you for posting on the forums. We wanted to reach out because you mentioned some concerning signs that demand medical attention. These medical concerns include - accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury - become suicidal - confused thinking and is not making any sense - delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren't there) -  disoriented; doesn‟t know what day it is, where they are or who they are - vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea - experiencing dizziness or fainting spells - too weak to walk or collapses - painful muscle spasms - complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing - blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit - a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16 - an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute) - cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees Fahrenheit If you’re experiencing coldness, pain, or any of the above, we recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. ERs are another available resource. The NEDA Helpline can be reached at 800.931.2237 Monday-Thursday 9-9 EST and Friday 9-5 EST for help in seeking more resources near you. Please stay safe.

column4: SEVERE pain and fatigue during recovery
column5: Hi Everyone,I am 55 y.o. and I have a 45+ year history of anorexia and over-exercise. I started my recovery approximately 3 1/2 months ago. I have stopped exercising completely and have been following my meal plan as best as I can. (There are days that I don't meet the requirements of my meal plan). When I embarked on my recovery, I continued to exercise but, scaled it WAY back. After a month or so, I had to be honest with myself and admit that I had increased the amount of time I was exercising and had doubled and tripled the amount of weight I was lifting. I took the leap and stopped completely. At the beginning of recovery, I dealt with severe insomnia (averaging 2-3 hours/night). After I stopped exercising, this severe fatigue and all over body pain set in with muscle cramping and extreme headaches. I also have poor memory, brain fog, tingling in my extremities and dizziness. It continues to get worse to the point that just going to the grocery store leaves me in so much pain with so much fatigue, I can barely move. I am feeling depressed and so ashamed of what I have done to my body. I wondered if any of you have dealt with this extreme pain and debilitating fatigue? I fully realize that because the length of time I had my ED, it is probably going to be a long recovery. But, I felt so much better when I was starving myself and over-exercising. How can that be?
column9:
Dear seeyaed, we would like to inform you that the symptoms you described are concerning. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:
Seek medical help soon on an outpatient basis if you:
We recommend that you seek medical help as soon as possible.

column5: my ED started getting bad when i was around 15 bc i was taking anxiety medication that made me sick and i couldnt eat, then i didnt want to eat bc i saw how skinny i got. ive been recovering for 6 years and a few months ago i was put on medication for my arthritis that had the same effect and i was eating a certain amount a day maximum but it no longer makes me nauseous so ive been working on eating more regularly. the last week or so ive been eating X meals a day and at first i didnt think about it but now i cant stop thinking about every calorie as i take every bite. ive been managing to still eat X meals a day but i have the urge to purge it and i almost always spit up the very last bite, its like my body is fighting against me and it wins at the very end. ive also been looking at calories, ive avoided it for so long and now i cant help but glance and then i have to try to physically shake it out of my head.

column5: I hate myself more than ever right now. My papa (grandpa) asked my mom on the phone when they were gonna come visit. I feel really upset about it, but there’s no way I could travel when the depression is this bad. But I figured, at least my parents could still go. But my mom said it would be stupid to leave me alone when I’m “totally depressed” and now it’s my fault none of us are going to see him. I love him more than anyone on this planet and I feel so guilty and worthless that my depression is ruining this for everyone. Since this doesn’t get better until January (this has happened every year for twelve years, same time of year, same length of time) that’s months until I can see him. I just hate myself and feel so guilty. My heart is heavy. On top of that, I’ve been forcing myself to follow my meal plan and it makes me feel so ashamed of my body. Rather than restricting which would make me feel better. But I’m trying to do the right thing, but somehow that’s the thing that feels worse.
