column5:
I’ve noticed somewhat recently that I start to feel comforted in the fact that though I’m choosing recovery now, that if life gets too much, another trauma occurs, or my depression doesn’t improve, I can always fall back into the eating disorder.
What is wrong with me??? Why would I think that, when I’ve worked so hard for the past six months at recovery, after I’ve gotten back on track after having more slips recently. I hate the eating disorder and what it did to me and the toll it took on so many aspects of my life. Why am I thinking about being comforted by it always being an option then???I’ve also been having a huge internal conflict that I finally understand better but is still hard to accept. I thought that by allowing myself to have a relationship with my father after he worked hard for the last five years to show he’s no longer abusive, accepting help for his mental illness, meds and using what he’s learned in therapy, by accepting that he’s changed and allowing a relationship meant that I was betraying myself in a way and saying that all the horrible things that happened is now okay. Logically, that’s not the truth, nor does he think that. He continues to take responsibility for his actions. But it’s caused an internal crisis. It’s not that I think forgiving him makes me weak. And he’s the only person in my family who has been supportive through my ED recovery.
I think the issue is that for the last five years, I’ve struggled with identity issues but one that I always defined myself as was someone who survived 21 years of abuse and was stronger for it, who was closed off to my family and better off without them. Now, my dad having to appear to have truly changed, almost angers me, not really at him, but just that the way I defined myself no longer applies. That by letting the person who caused the events that hardened my heart support me and have a relationship, I’m somehow too soft or weak and I honestly have no idea who I am without that part of my identity. Yet as I’ve said, his behavior has truly changed once he got help for his mental illness after I stood up to him five years ago, and his support seems genuine. I’m just really confused about all of this and would appreciate any input or insight you guys might have.
column9: Hi, tryingtobebrave and savedbygrace. We're very sorry to hear about what happened to you both. We wanted to post up some resources in case you ever need to speak to someone. Crisis Text Line: Text "NEDA" to 741-741 or www.crisistextline.orgNational Suicide Prevention Lifeline: (800) 273-8255 or www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org RAINN: (800) 656-4673 or www.rainn.orgDomestic Abuse Hotline: (800) 799-7233

column5: My girlfriend has been recovered for 4 years (I've known her for two). I never knew her when she had bulimia, but we talked about the experience and her recovery. I thought it was behind her. She's been going through a lot of stress lately, and recently told me she's had X binge/purge episodes in the last month. I was calm when she told me this and was supportive. But honestly I don't know what to do. I've been researching lapses and trying to understand next steps. I never thought I'd be in this position with her. She's very against professional/clinical help, as she had a lot of poor experiences with it in the past. It's seems like a coping mechanism for the stress in her life, so my instinct is to help her make changes to remove the stress, but I'm not a professional. I want to help her, but I don't know what to do next?
column9: Hi, benberk27! We're sorry to hear about your girlfriend's struggles. We're glad that you are reaching out for some support through the forums. Part of your post has been edited because use of specific numbers that might be triggering for other members. Please take a look at our community guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines. Please feel free to take a look at our recovery and relapse page here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/learn/general-information/recovery. If you need additional resources you're more than welcome to reach out to the NEDA Helpline at (800) 931-2237 (Monday - Thursday 9 AM - 9 PM EST Friday 9 AM - 5 PM EST) or chat with us (top right hand corner).

column5: I've been feeling extra anxious lately with the windy, wet, intimidating weather currently been experiencing for the last month, or so...I find myself eating more than i should on the days i am not scheduled to work. Furthermore, after binging and purging i lull myself to sleep. Out of anxiety last night, I purged.Ironically this old feeling of apathy over food coming back up, after a food frenzy,  reminded me of my "Old School" days back in HS, college and even grad school too. I have been eating healthy but then there are these periods of days when I stuff on certain food and these are the days in which I also become kind of apathetic to my oral hygiene. I feel embarrassed to even see my dentist, whom currently I don't have 1 on standby...I feel embarrassed that after 1 look at my teeth they will be able to assess my eating and habits.With just 1 look into my mouth, and a few good inquisitive questions,  and the dentist,  or hygienist,   will know about my dental apathy from both my EdI see a shrink about every 3 months but he never seems to look at my teeth. He sits behind a desk and goes over a list of similar questions about my meds, and level of functioning which I am feeling every 3 months.I wish my shrink knew me as well as my ex-BF or BFF's. I miss my inner circle of friends from college.I love working as it keeps me so busy that I hardly have time to eat certain foods or to act apathetic. I feel a part of my local community at my mall job. I floss my teeth before I leave for my mall job. Considering how i feel sometimes, it seems like work keeps me functioning at a higher level mentally. I feel like Wonder Woman at work,   and on my days off,   like the lazy version of Louis Lane,  the average secretariat,  before her antidepressant kicks in,   and she is able to save the world,   once over,    again, and again...each and every time she ends up looking like a real hero...  OMG, I think I need to increase my exercise,  and see if that's what I really need to do to activate my motivation to improve my overall health and re-dress my current, intermittent feeling of apathy... I'm sure I don't need an additional psych med for this problem. This is an elbow to mouth, and lack of motivation problem that I must work on.Will i ever be able to meet the "Love" of my life and marry and have a "Normal Life?"This seems like a Total mystery to me. I feel so sheltered from people most of the time that i just stopped socializing in public except for work. This can't possibly be "Normal"  right?
column9: Hi, chunkymonkey68, portions of your post have been edited and deleted since they contained specific, graphic details as well as information that might be triggering for other members. Please take a look at our community guidelines: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines

column5: I feel very stuck. I'm not underweight or malnourished. Even when I was inpatient because of a screwy heart and severe malnutrition, I was only at the lower end of healthy. Now that I've gained some weight I'm at the higher end of healthy. But I can't seem to help myself with behaviors. I can't stop the binging. Even when I stop restricting and try to eat well I still binge. I usually purge after the binge but I even tried stopping that. The binging continued. I feel like there's no point in stopping any of it if I'm still going to binge.It feels like binging is all I have. I have no close friends, I don't think I have for years. My father is impossible to live with. My depression has taken away all my drive for life. I can't concentrate on my school work anymore. I can't talk to people. It just doesn't feel like a quality of life and I wish I could at least lose weight. It won't make me "happy" but it gives me something to look forward to.
column9: Dear tryingtofindreason,Welcome to the NEDA Forums. It sounds like you're going through a difficult time and we are concerned about your safety. We understand youmay be feeling hopeless right now,and we all feel this way sometimes. However, help is available and people do get through dark times.This number is really important to have: (800)273-TALK(8255). If you don't feel comfortable talking, please text "NEDA" to 741741 or visit one of these websites: http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/ - or click to chat  http://www.dialhelp.org/?page_id=7759 or text 906-356-3337 http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/ or text 741-741 http://unsuicide.wikispaces.com/Online+Suicide+Help+Wiki#.UcNaxKwfHt0 https://www.imalive.org/ or call 800-784-2433

column5:
It had been 5 years since I had bulimic tendencies. Then, I kept being cut off by friends I cared about and thought they cared as well. Then I had unknown stomach pain for 6 months, and then I became depressed. I got help and then I met this guy who said he loved me, and he helped me through some of these problems. Then he dropped off the planet and my eating disorder changed where I started restricting. It has been six months and since I recently saw him again I became triggered and my eating disorder reappeared. It makes me feel so much shame because I keep doing well for a little while and then I go back. I wonder if it will ever end. I know that hope exists. I believe God doesn't want us to suffer, but life is hard. What if it keeps getting worse ?
Just keep fighting is what I keep telling myself.
column9: Dear Stronger7, Welcome to the NEDA Forums! A portion of your post was edited and deleted due to the mention of specific behaviors that may be triggering to others. Our community guidelines are always available to review here:  http://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/community-guidelines. In the event you need further assistance, please do not hesitate to call the NEDA helpline at 1-800-931-2237 (Monday-Thursday 9:00am-9:00pm, Friday 9:00am-5:00pm EST). Since you also mentioned having some issues with your stomach we just wanted to post some signs and symptoms of a medical emergency just in case. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:• accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury• become suicidal• confused thinking and is not making any sense• delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiencing dizziness or fainting spells• too weak to walk or collapses• painful muscle spasms• complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing• blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees FahrenheitOr any other serious medical concernsIf you experience any of the above, we highly recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. Another option is to call 911.

column5: Hi all!I'm a survivor of AN and looking for a blog which I was reading 5 years ago during recovery phase.The blog is written by an Asian-American survivor of an eating disorder where she talks about her recovery process over a few years. A couple of things I remember were that she worked at olive garden for a while, went to university and went for walks, needed her meals at specific times or got very upset and that her parents had to stop supporting her at one point since it was very hard.If anyone knows which blog this is, please link me! I would like to read it again.For anyone who is having trouble with a recent ED, I promise it gets better, keep working at recovery. I've been recovered for 5 years, attended uni and graduated, and had some great experiences which I never imagined I would be able to experience. My life is free from exercise and food obsessive thoughts, and I love life.Sending love to everyone!
column9: Hi, nja729! Welcome to the forums! We hope that you or another member are able to find this blog! We're really glad to hear that you're in recovery! Please take a look at our community guidlines: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines. If you need any additional support, please feel free to reach out to the NEDA Helpline at (800) 931 - 2237 (Monday - Thursday 9 AM - 9 PM EST Friday 9 AM - 5 PM EST) or chat with us (top right hand corner)!

column5: I’m currently in ED treatment, and just stepped up from IOP to PHP to get more assistance/accountability with meal plan adherence. My current diagnosis is BED, though for most of my life I’ve been bulimic. I’ve been abstinent from purging for six years until last night, when the increased ED noise from treatment got unbearable and I tried to purge again.  Without going into details, it was unsatisfying and didn’t work like it used to to get my anger out. I made it back to treatment today and was honest about my behavior, but I’m really feeling a confusing mix of grief (that my old standby behaviors aren’t successfully stuffing feelings), hope (that it’s probably a sign of health that I’m not successfully stuffing feelings), and relief (that my lack of success limits my desires to get into a behavior cycle). I’m also having to resist the urge to escalate by using purging aids. Does anyone have experience to share on what’s helped you to see past the loss of familiar behaviors to life worth living?  I feel like my ultimate fallback safety valve has been cut, and it’s pretty discouraging right now.
column9: Hi, rainbowcrane and iwanttolive, since there has been mention of past self harm we just wanted to post up some resources where you or anyone else on this forum can talk or chat with in case there is a time where you're struggling with these thoughts. Crisis Text Line: Text "NEDA) to 741-741 or www.crisistextline.org National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: (800) 273 - 8255 or www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org S.A.F.E: (800) 366 - 8288 or www.selfinjury.com

column5: Hi everyone. I am new to this forum and I have been in recovery from anorexia for about 6 months now. I lost my period about a year and a half ago, but I still have yet to have one. Is it true that it is necessary to eat a certain amount of calories a day in order to heal and get your period back? Right now I am considered to be at a "normal" BMI, even though I know that i a pretty controversial tool to use to indicate whether or not someone is healthy. Anyway, I am still having a hard time grappling with eating so many calories because I am scared of gaining more and more weight and not stopping. I also currently weight train X days per week, so I know I need to eat more to compensate for that.

column5: Hi, I am 24..I suffer from ED since 2011/12..first i had anorexia (for half year maybe?) then it has turn into binge eating. I am still underweight bcs i compensate the binges..but my bodyfat % is normal i would say..as i Dont exercise.In 2014 i lost my period. To be honest i Dont understand why i havent Gót it back when i eat enough and during binges even more.I Dont want to have children but i believe i should have IT anyway...but how? Thanks

column5: I need to make changes and am totally terrified. I am stressed with work i am off this week and couldn't be happier but my therapist told me i always think the grass is greener and I end up just as unhappy when i move somewhere else but i just feel trapped in my job right now. I am considering going back to school but am sort of terrified like what if that is a mistake and i fail and well end up like i did last time i went to school with well no new job and a lot of debt which well thank god my parents help pay for school. if i go back its all on me money wise its a big decision and i just don't know. I also quit my boxing club because after i was not allowed to exercise i just couldn't motivate myself to go back now i sort of regret it but if i go back to school i would have no time to go to classes. i might just join a cheaper gym that could work on my schedule even if i don't go back to school i think my own schedule might just be easier than going to classes i can be my own boss but i don't really want to get out of control either but i think working out in a healthy way could be good to but my boxing gym was very expensive and missing it would make me feel guilty as it cost so much... i need to make changes to myself to me my life and well just all of it my therapist told me she doesn't want me to be a statistic and well she is right she said my friends and family just want me to be happy and healthy. It was a tough love session today and i have a lot to process but i know she is right. she was my best friend who died therapist too she said it hurts you every day her loss and she said she hears from my friends mom and she said she lost a person too and i get that she is right and the reason my friend died was yes her eating disorder. I want to be strong i just don't believe i am that strong...

column4: Sexual development in teenage after eating disorder
column5: Hi. I'm a college freshman girl who recently turned 18. I suffered from a restrictive eating disorder since I was 14, lost my period for one-ish years and got it back. After that, I managed to gain weight, but I kind of switched to other symptoms like eating and purging. I'm not completely symptom free, but now the interval of purging has increased a lot and I personally believe that I gained enough weight. (Upper half in the normal weight BMI scale) However, I somehow feel like my body and mind isn't developing sexually. Parts of my body started developing, however, not as much as compared to my friends. Also, I don't feel anything sexual. I haven't fell in love before and I never have loved anyone in terms of 'wanting to date'. Do you think this is normal and that I should give it some more time? Or should I go see a doctor or a professional and ask them what might be going on?
column9: Hi, savedbygrace. We're sorry that part of the post was triggering. We have edited some parts out as well. We just wanted to post some resources in case you or anyone else on these forums need to reach out. RAINN: www.rainn.org or call (800) 656 - 4673.

column5: I had a pretty tough day today. One of my biggest trauma triggers happened, my therapist calls it a capital “T” trauma, meaning for me those are the memories in which I thought / was about to die. These don’t happen often for me, but when they do they’re completely incapacitating. Can’t move, can’t speak. I canceled plans with a friend, curled up shaking in a ball in my bed. This is actually an improvement, as I used to hide in the closet when this happened. I thought about using restriction all day, but I got my meal plan in and only restricted a bit. I’m not beating myself up over it because it’s still an improvement. I used healthy skills, mainly distraction, instead of harmful ways to cope. I ended up having to take my medication; my psychiatrist prescribed a heavier dose for me. It gets me back to reality and the present without adrenaline pumping through my system. I slept a lot after that. I’m going to bed now even though it’s only 6:40. I hope tomorrow will be better.

column5:
The week after next, I have my annual checkup with my cardiologist (I have sinus tachycardia, not from ED). This will be the first time he’ll have learned about my eating disorder. He’s a really good doctor and not judgemental but I’m nervous about when the nurses put my information in the computer, they always ask about diet and exercise. It’s stupid to be anxious about but I feel really embarrassed. My dietician said to tell them that I’m in recovery from anorexia and am working with a dietician. I feel stupid even posting about this.
I’m still having a hard time with my best friends mom dying suddenly and my other best friend being diagnosed with Parkinson’s, and my depression still isn’t improving. After I get my thyroid checked (I have hypothyroidism) and make sure I don’t need my medication adjusted, I’m going to talk to my psychiatrist about switching to a different antidepressant. I’m tired of feeling so down.

column5: It is so difficult living with people.  Especially judgmental and critical people.  I bought a house gift for the three or us.  Our cabinets are messy with a bunch of mismatched containers for food.  I bought a very nice 38 piece set of containers and my roommate was cold and saying I use all of those in there, you aren't thinking of throwing them all out?  And you will have to organize all the other containers and sort through them because I certainly am not going to.  I was so hurt.  I think angry too if I were to be honest.  Always being criticized and underhandedly too, and then when my sister and I talk, she always has to challenge everything I say and questions everything, and wonders why I get upset.   Just a bit of a let down after a really nice day.  But I get to choose here.  I can let it ruin my mood, or not.  I am going to choose to not let it ruin my mood.  I am in control of that.  I don't need food to numb out or restricting to numb out or self harm.  I am beyond these ways of coping with rejection. That is how I see it.  Rejection.  When together with family, I am never heard. I try to talk and no one hears me.  Feeling judge and criticized all the time is a tough way to live.  But I have friends that love me and accept me and aren't critical of me.  And most of all, my faith in Jesus and knowing that He is enough.  I don't need anything more.  That is how I have been trying to live my life.  One can take anything away from me, even through me in prison, but the one thing that can't be taken away from me is Jesus.  So I am going to rest with that thought, organize the cabinet sometime tomorrow or the next day and give my roommate all the containers that are old.  I hope you all have a good night.  Thank you for listening.  Remember.  The only one we can control, on a good day, is ourselves.   The way we react to situations, people, events.  That is up to us.  We can not control other people, how they react to us, or treat us.  We decide how we react to what is going on.   Tonight I am choosing to relax before I go to sleep soon and be thankful for such a nice day.iwanttolive

column5: Hi.  Thank you for your response.  Just to comment on wasting another year, God says He uses all things for good for those that love Him and are called according to His purpose.  God doesn't waste anything.  I am sure you learned a lot this year and have grown.  You may still be struggling with symptoms but you are not where you were a year ago.  You are sharing here to others on the forum and supporting others, you are helping with your sisters, you just graduated from college.  These are huge.  You are working on being honest with your team, by the way, how did it go with the doctor?  I think it is you who was going to the cardiologist?   Sometimes I get people mixed up, sorry if I did.  The only time things are a waste is when we give up and stop trying.  Taking a break is okay and sometimes needed.  But that is different than giving up and the last time I knew, you haven't given up.  You are indeed a recovery warrior.  You are flexing that recovery muscle.   Think of that when you can't physically exercise.  Exercise spiritually as well.  That is where this war is to be fought.  With prayer.  With God's help.  Don't beat yourself up.  Try to be kind to yourself. Accept yourself for who you are.  You are special and have something unique to offer this world.  With love,                                                    iwanttolive

column5: Hello! I’m currently recovering from restrictive eating, before hand I would binge eat. I was overweight and began excersicing and restricting food. Since realising I had all these crazy food rules and always thiught about food I’ve began eating normally, I got my period back by eating balanced, whoo! But a month since getting my period back, extreme hunger has kicked in. For the past month I’ve been eating uncontrollably to the point of feeling so sick and uncomfortable , my Stomach genuinely hurts! I’ve been concentrating on not restricting everything and giving my all to recovery listening to my body. I believe my body’s caught up and is recovered but my mind is taking longer. I’m worried this is turning into binge eating disorder. I’ve put on a lot of weight - it doesn’t bother me I just want to recover and be healthy but I constantly am in pain and am so full! How can I curb this hunger/bingingThank u !!

column5:
I'm a mum of two beautiful young boys.
After battling with anorexia and bulimia for 10 years.... I've decided enough is enough. I fell the lowest weight last month and the thought of me being poorly and my boys terrified me.
I've been in a constant binge for weeks and the weight has been piling on. Seriously I feel so awful about it. When will it distribute around effectively? It's making me feel as if I can slip back at any moment as my belly was a main trigger for me.
Any advice? Thank you. X

column5: Hi everyone. This is my first post, and I'm desperate to have a connection with someone anyone who has any idea what I'm going though so I don't feel so alone. Here it goes... Although I've had body image issues my entire life my ED really came out the summer between my senior year of high school and freshman year of college. During the summer, I lost weight organically working out and eating very little. I thought i was happy and still thought I could lose a little more. My goal weight kept shifting lower. Thus, when I got to college and pressures for school and social life began to kick in, I turned to bulimia to satisfy my need to for food and my desire to be thin and keep up appearances. I binged and purged almost every day beginning in October until Decemeber when I was caught by my family who had noticed the change in my eating habits. This is where my problem begins. My mother is a worrier and a punisher. Her knee jerk reaction was to pull me out of school, cancel my spring break plans, etc. Essentially put my entire life on stop. I did not want this. I was finally making friends at school? I was happy, I could not stay in my mundane hometown. So, I lied. I said I was better than I actually was and promised to seek therapy once back at school for the winter semester. I did. And I did get better. I was no longer binging and purging everyday, but I was still unhappy with who I was and partaking in unhealthy eating patterns (skipping meals, overexercising, etc.). I felt like this is what I had to do to stay "pretty" — what I convinced myself I was for the first time when I had lost the weight. When I returned home for the summer, I had done my part convincing them that I was healthy and no moments of relapse or negative thinking assciated with my weight, I still feel as though there has been a shift in our relationship. I am afraid of being honest with them because I know that if I show any signs of slipping up, they will take away the life I have worked so hard to build while away at college. This mistrust sowed combined with the natural growing pains associated with coming home from college have put a strain on my parents and my relationship. I hate coming home. I feel like I am walking on eggshells, waiting to be caught for something and have my world taken away. I hate being at home. I was not popular in high school and have virtually no friends at home. My worst nightmare is being stuck here again. I feel like my world slows down. I feel depressed not only because of the slowness and anxiety that encapsulates my home life, but also because I have no one (but my at-school therapist who i barely see anymore because of scheduling conflicts) to talk to about this. None of my friends know about my ED as I am too afraid that our relationship will be forever strained and changed by such a revelation. I don't think that they will look at me the same, so I have kept them in the dark. My sister is a snitch who without a doubt will give me unsolicited advice and run and tell my parents. I am just looking for someone to talk these issues out with. Please anyone. Be there for me. I'll listen to anyone'sissues
column9: Hello and welcome to the forums alexaowens35! Your post was edited slightly to remove specific numbers that may be triggering to other forum members. You can find the community guidelines here:  https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines

column5:
Horrible things have happened with my two best friends. One of whom, her mother just died. I asked her if she needed space or rather I keep checking in with her. She asked me to keep in contact often, and I have been. The funeral is tomorrow (I’m not able to attend) , and I’ll see her on Friday. I feel awful for not asking if she would like my to attend, but I have two therapy appointments and one with my dietician tomorrow. It’s a balancing act with supporting her and keeping myself healthy. I really want to step up for her because she did for my when I was in treatment, even came to family night when I was in PHP to learn how to support me.
My other best friend was just diagnosed with Parkinson’s and doesn’t want to take the medication which is the only thing that would slow down the progression, and in his case, it will happen a lot faster without it. I can’t stand the thought of watching my best friend waste away. But I can’t force him to follow through with the treatment.
All of these things hit me tonight, and I exercised way past what my dietician and I last discussed, even on top of my already screwed up knee, I really messed it up now. I physically won’t be able to exercise even if I get the urges. I didn’t realize why I had this compulsion until I started sobbing about everything that’s happening afterwards. Again, need to stop ignoring my emotions.
I am glad I’m seeing my dietician tomorrow as i really need to talk to her about the exercise issue I keep struggling with.
Sorry this was so long. Thanks for listening.
column8: trying to be brave, we are
column9: tryingtobebrave, we are sorry you are going through so much right now as well as dealing with your own recovery. We are glad you are here and able to write about everything, and hope that you find comfort in knowing how many people care about you!In the event you or anyone else needs these numbers: NEDA contact: Helpline 1-800-931-2237 Chat at www.myneda.org, text "NEDA" to 741741https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org/chat/1-800-273-8255S.A.F.E. 1-800-366-8388 or www.selfinjury.com

column5: I saw my dietician yesterday, and we changed my exercise contract. My eating disorder is actually louder now though, constantly there telling me to burn calories. My dietician states often enough that exercise for me is not to burn calories, but for my mental health and physical wellbeing. I learned some new skills to try to reroute those thoughts during exercising and when I bodycheck and compare my body with others. I will be putting an effort into doing these things. But a part of me misses my eating disorder. Especially with how much I struggle during winter, a part of me desperately wishes I was using behaviors to make all the feelings, thoughts and memories disappear. I am so used to having numbed out my feelings for most of my life, that anytime i experience a negative emotion it makes me feel like I’m going out of control. Which when it passes, I realize is not the case. I miss the feelings I got from my past disordered behaviors. However I will not go back down that road, as life as a whole is much better in recovery than relapse. The same always goes from my addiction, I’ve just been sober a lot longer than I’ve been in recovery from my eating disorder. My best friends mom died very suddenly yesterday, she’s only in her 30s and has now lost both her parents. My heart hurts very badly for her. I feel so angry at all the things she’s had to suffer through, it seems like it never ends. I know all I can do is to support her in whatever way she needs me to. And that’s motivation to not use behaviors, because I need to be healthy in order to support her. Thanks for listening.

column5: Checking in to see how you are doing.  Haven't heard from you in a while.  How did the paper turn out?
column9: We're sorry to hear that you fainted at your sister's basketball game. We understand you're going into an inpatient program, however, we just wanted to post the signs and symptoms of a medical emergency just in case as you mentioned fainting. The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:• accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury• become suicidal• confused thinking and is not making any sense• delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiencing dizziness or fainting spells• too weak to walk or collapses• painful muscle spasms• complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing• blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees FahrenheitOr any other serious medical concernsIf you experience any of the above signs and symptoms, we recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. Another option is 911.

column5:
Hi there! I am 26 years old and have been struggling with BED for the past 11 years. I began using food as a coping mechanism during my sophomore year of highschool. During that time, I was very depressed and unhappy. I won't go much into depth on the details since it is the past. I've moved on since then. I have been on two rounds of antidepressants throughout the past 10 years as well as seen 3 therapists off and on. I have currently been off antidepressants for over 2 years nor have I seen a therapist during the course of that time. I began to fear that antidepressants would be the norm for me, but I have realized that it isn't the case. The past two years I have been handling my BED disorder quite well. I even went months without doing so last year. However, it is rearing its ugly head again. I have moved four times in the course of five years with my husband's job. Restarting over and over--adjusting okay during the course. I have realized over the past two weeks that I think I am actually depressed...not in the traditional sense of being sad. However, I lack motivation to do anything. Going to the grocery store each week has become something I dread simply because I am finding it so immensely daunting Outside of work (I am a workaholic--in a job that I don't necessarily enjoy) I can't seem to find motivation to do anything (besides run). I eat, sleep, and watch tv, and sit (thinking about things I want to do). I've decided that how I am feeling isn't normal. I am lagging...big time. Nonetheless, my episodes of binging are coming back... My husband is away for a month with work and I am worried....TERRIFIED of BED gaining control over me again. I am currently going to the doctor to get a referral for a therapist. I need support. This is why I am here. I feel alone. I feel guilty and defeated and I need hope. I will admit I don't have friends and I am exhausted from starting over.
For anyone who reads this, thank you. I just need someone....anyone to talk to. Even if that someone doesn't reply. I need to feel heard. I have no one to hold me accountable and I will be honest I don't know if I can trust myself right now. Blogging has helped me in the past. I pray that it will be helpful once again. Tomorrow WILL be a better day. I have to forgive myself and move on. I know I am not a failure, but boy do I feel like one right now.

column5: I have been overly emotional since i got home from vacation and i finally discussed with my psychiatrist about why i went off my meds and well i am not clear why i did or if it was just destructive. my team talked and they are not sure if i was almost manic after i went back on they dont' know because i don't have a timeline i basically went off was depressed and suicidal and then had a time when i was like just doing whatever and spending a ton of money and not caring and stuff so just out of character for me they are just trying to make sense of it...
column9: Hi hermoine3,It sounds like what you are going through right now is extremely difficult for you and it is understandable to be scared and afraid or even confused about what is going on. We know things can seem at times hopeless but remember WE care about you and are concerned about your wellbeing! It is really important that you have this information and that you contact them immediately or when you start to feel lost or unsafe again: (800)273-TALK(8255). I would like you to contact that number. If you don't feel comfortable talking, please text "NEDA" to 741741 or visit one of these websites: http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/ - or click to chat  http://www.dialhelp.org/?page_id=7759 or text 906-356-3337 http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/ or text 741-741 http://unsuicide.wikispaces.com/Online+Suicide+Help+Wiki#.UcNaxKwfHt0 https://www.imalive.org/ or call 800-784-2433  https://nycwell.cityofnewyork.us/en/

column5: Hi everyone!my first post here.. I have always just browsed :). I have been in recovery for quite some time and just had my first REAL period in years! I am on the non-hormonal IUD. I am having some bad thoughts though. My period was about 7 days and I understandably gained a certain amount of weight a week-ish before. However, It has been about 14 days since I first bloated and I am still feeling VERY bloated and gassy. My face has broken out pretty badly too! I thought these were exclusively pms symptoms? I'm trying really hard not to restrict again. Has this happened to any of you on your first period in a while? Is it normal for it to be longer/more intense? Thanks!

column5: Reality blows... my laptop needs to be replaced and I just spent so much money on vacation and I need one but I just couldn’t even think when they talked to me today at the store...I woke up at 3 am and couldn’t fall back asleep I got my period for the first time in a while and it is a trauma trigger and eating disorder stress...and the cramps awful and then had diarrhea and no it is just stress all my doctors say so it was all nerves about work oh and work awful I guess at the meeting I missed our boss said we have not earned a holiday party or deserve it I was like are you serious we work so hard my coworker told me she blew up at our office manager saying the staff is treated like shit and it hurts the kids and morale is basically in the toliet which is so true we are all miserable and way to motivate we don’t deserve a party wow... I just don’t know and then of course I got a latte on my way to check out my laptop my latte somehow spilled all over my car... and Thursday would have been my best friends birthday who died 3 years ago...I am of course more emotional due to my period but just I can’t my job is awful I applied at some I did get a phone interview but don’t know how I did it was automated...I just need out of this job

The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention:• accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury• become suicidal• confused thinking and is not making any sense• delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiencing dizziness or fainting spells• too weak to walk or collapses• painful muscle spasms• complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing• blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees Fahrenheit Or any other serious medical concernsIf you experience any of these, we highly recommend you seek medical attention as soon as possible. Another option is 911. Also, if needed please text: "NEDA" to 741 - 741 or www.crisistextline.org/get-help-now. Call (800) 273- 8255 or www.suicidepreventionline.org

column5: Feelings are so powerful.  Feeling sad, mad, happy, angry, funny, hopeful.  Most of these are tolerable, unless the happy gets a little too out of hand and one is told to be quiet, you are being to loud, or then comes the one that is really tough for me, the feeling of sad.  What to do with this one.  I used to eat.  Or starve it away.  Now, I am trying to talk, post, will talk to God, haven't yet, read, watch a movie, however the movie I watched was a sad one so that didn't help.  So when in recovery and use of behaviors is no longer an option, texting a therapist isn't an option, talking to the parent's about the situation isn't an option, as it was decided it wouldn't be regarding this particular situation anymore, and it really doesn't help any of us anyway, what does one do?  I guess the afore mentioned things.  Prayer for some of us, distraction for a while until the intensity of the feeling goes down to a more manageable level.  In DBT there are the zones.  I don't remember them but I know there is the one that is out of the window of tolerance, then inside the window of tolerance and then below the window of tolerance.  Something like that. Right now I am below, which means my mood is low, below the norm. I need to get it into the norm.  If I were angry it would be outside the window and I would need to bring it down into the level of average.  For so many decades, I used self harm, starvation and binging, none of which do I use anymore, so I need to do something.  One of the things is posting here, another is prayer, and then reading.  I also color but am too tired to do that now.  So I will end this, say a prayer and ask God for help then read.  I am thankful that I no longer use behaviors that don't work anyways, at least not in the long term.  I just needed to post as I am very sad.  Feeling alone.  Sad and lonely.  I guess they often go together.  Thanks for listening.iwanttolive

column5: In two weeks I will be finishing up the documentary on my life and recovery from suffering with eating disorders and self harm.  I am very excited.  It will be put out on some form of social media.  I do not know which.  But in the new year it should be done.  My parent's will be talking about their journey through this with me.  And how it affected them.  And the joy we all have at the change that God has brought forth in my life.  So excited.  iwanttolive

column5: I’ve made a great new friend recently. We do fun stuff together, and it helps me work on being open to trying new things. I feel like I can be myself around this person, and it’s a good friendship. I’m getting down and frustrated at myself though, because a lot of the time I feel like I can’t keep up. I’m only in my twenties, but I don’t do a lot of things people my age tend to. I’m not “fun” I feel like. Due to my physical and mental health, I’m starting to feel really stressed about giving time and attention to all my friendships. I have a lot of appointments during the week, and I always make some time for being social, but I also need rest days in between to recuperate. Inside I feel like I’m 80, not mid twenties. I’m just tired and stressed and not sure how to handle this issue. I’m also planning on finally going to driving school in the spring, I feel like I’m ready to start EMDR around trauma with driving, so I can move forward. Then comes moving out, and my new friend is a potential roommate, and I’m not sure on the timeline or things, and feel like I’m going to let them down. Basically, great new friendship, overwhelmed with how to make time for them all and still take care of my physical and mental health
column9: Sorry to hear that you're struggling with feeling tired. We wanted to provide with a list of signs and symptoms of a medical emergency to keep an eye on: A person does not have to be underweight to have an eating disorder or to require emergency medical care for one.Seek medical help immediately if your loved one:• accidentally or deliberately causes themselves a physical injury• becomes suicidal• experiences confused thinking and is not making any sense• experiences delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there)• feels disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are• vomits several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea• experiences dizziness or fainting spells• feels too weak to walk or collapses• experiences painful muscle spasms• complains of chest pain or having trouble breathing• observes blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit• has a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16• has an irregular heartbeat or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute)• has cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees Fahrenheit Or for any other serious medical concerns. If you notice that you're struggling with anything on this list, we highly recommend seeking medical attention as soon as possible. Another options is 911.

column5: Hi everyone. Hope you are all doing okay and being kind to yourselves. I want to do something really crazy. I want to ask my sisters to tell me exactly what they think of me. What they talk about with each other about me, without me knowing. I want to know what they say about me. I know it isn't good. I know they don't really have positive things to say about me. But I want to know up font. Straight from them. Tell me who you think I am, what I do wrong and why you don't like me. What do you talk with each other about me that I only know that there are many, oh, I meant to say a few, says one of them; actually two of my sisters said that. One lives across the country and hasn't spent more than a week with the family and that was more than five years ago. She doesn't even know me or who I am yet she makes judgements about me. I know they talk about me. SO.. tell me what you say to each other. Get it out in the open. Let me know what you really think about me. I really want to send that e mail out. They say I am the sick one because I was the one who was so sick with the eating disorder. They would never admit that eating disorders are family disorders. I was the one with all the problems. I could go on and list all the problems my sisters have now. Why won't they just accept me and love me. They may say it with words, but words mean nothing without action. I have lived my life as the reject of the family. I guess I still do. Such a shame. I know who I am. Who I belong to. Whos I am. I am a child of The Most High God. He calls me His own. He says He loves me. He cherishes me. He gave His life for me. He calls me His friend. What more could a person ask for. So if my sisters don't like me, I have a great many friends and people who do. And God loves me. So, I end with that. iwanttolive and I still do even after the pain I experienced today. Because He lives, I can face tomorrow.

column4: Working Hard and Weight is Down
column5: So I had a lot of muscle pains today and took some aspirin-caffeine pills to medicate my cramps. At the end of my work day at school, after re-arranging the chairs, and even lifting 1 to move it into place, I finally was surprised to have my period return in full force. I panicked and ran to the restroom. There I felt really anxious and a bit weak to my head. I made it home right on time before another high tide episode w/ my period occurred. I had a small portion meal for dinner and wasn't much hungry after this sudden menstrual hemorrhage. I think the mix of caffeine and aspirin plus the heavy lifting of chairs brought on a heavy menstrual flow which was due about 2.5 months ago. Oh well, I finally had my period and thanks to my strength being used to restore the room at end of the day I actually took control over something which I was feeling quite powerless over. I was so tired of having to bloat, and cramping and feeling depressed over my body doing this to me. Thank God my only teaching assignment begins tomorrow after 11 AM... I also am scheduled for my PM retail job, and that makes me nervous. My PM retail job requires me to be on my feet almost the entire shift. If my P is heavy tomorrow I won't be able to go to work. My co-worker said if we call in a missed day, ill or whatever reason during now until Xmas,   that we could lose more attendance employee points. I can't help it. If I need a night off I must do what is necessary for me.

column5: Im new to this site and to seeking help online in general but I feel as though I need to reach out to clear my mind.im not sure if this is the right forum or if this could be triggering so please read with caution. I was diagnosed with anorexia nervosa with binge/purge subtype about 4 years ago and have been recovered for about 1.5 years now. I stopped attending regular therapy at the one year mark and now just go in if I feel the need to, which rarely happens as I'm always busy with college and other things.I gained alot of weight in recovery and when I stopped therapy I was at a healthy size for my height. However, for the months after the binging was out of control. My restrictive tendencies weren't there but the constant need to binge never faded with it.I went up Jean size and something jn my mind clicked. Now I feel as though I'm becoming too preoccupied with my weight. We don't keep scales in the house but I'm always looking in the mirror and feel awful about my body. I've also started keeping track of my calorie intake again after a year of not counting. I'm not restricting, just being very cautious and anxious about not eating over the recommended amount. Could this be a sign of relapse? I'm not sure if I should be worried at this point.I'm sorry for the whole essay question. I'm just becoming really concerned. Any input would really be appreciated and put my mind at ease.

column9: If you need to talk or need access to resources, NEDA can help. If you feel you are in crisis, please contactn helpline 1-800-931-2237, chat at www.myneda.org or text "NEDA" to 741741. You can also contact the Crisit Intervention center - https://cicla.org/

column5: Hi every one.  I am going to flex my recovery muscle again and I signed up for a college course at my local community college.  My therapist has been consistently urging me to do this and I have many excuses as to why I can't do that, from not being smart enough, never having learned how to write a term paper to not being able to remember what is being said.  Well, she would have none of this so I enrolled. It is payed in full by a pell grant, even my books.  I am able to have help with the disabilities resource department, which allows me to record the classes, take tests in the resource room, take breaks by walking out of the class if I need to and all the help I will need to write a paper at their writing lab where other students will help tutor me in writing a paper if one is required.  The class I want isn't being offered the spring semester, but will probably be offered in the fall.  So the class I am taking is addictions counselling.  My Mom is so happy for me, she wants to buy me a hoodie from the school.  She is so wonderful and a great advocate for me.  I am scared as college is a scary thing and I was very ill when I attempted to go before.  I have a lot of bad memories, but I am going to make new memories and again, flex my recovery muscle.I never say "my eating disorder', even when I was active in the behaviors and now when talking about it in the past tense.  I never want to give it that power and it never owned me.  But I am saying "my" recovery muscle because it is positive and it goes beyond the addictions to food and use of behaviors, including self harm, restrictive eating and overeating.  These things are past tense now.  Sometimes I am tempted to self soothe by eating and I have to ask myself, Am I hungry?  What is the reason I want this food?  What purpose is it serving?  What can I do besides eating when I don't need to.  I am not perfect at it but I am no longer overeating or binging or restricting.  There may be times I eat more than I need, but I then go through those questions and am able to call out to God and redirect.  I read a lot now, something even a few months ago I was unable to do.  I love to read and was so sad that my concentration had become so poor that I was unable to read.  So now I am in the middle of two books.  I am trying to finish the one as it is a library book, then another one from the library, then I will finish one a friend gave me.So off to  school I go on January 23rd.  Why they call it the spring semester when it is in the middle of the winter I will never know but that is what it is.  Take care and thank you for reading this.iwanttolive

column5: Hi there! I've been in recovery for the last five years, after a 17 year battle with AN and BN. I finally reached the point 5 years ago when the stars aligned at I was able to stop my ED behaviors. Been living with the guidelines of (a) no food is bad food, (b) make your life bigger than your eating disorder, and (c) you cannot try to change your body. And it has worked, for a long time. But, for some reason... its hard to remember those guidelines these days.I thought I was over this. Things have been really good for a long time, and most of the time, I don't even think about my ED, let alone have urges. But the last six months or so have had a lot of changes - moving multiple times, being far from family and friends, starting grad school and a new field of work - all sorts of things. And my ED has started creeping back in. I've been afraid to admit it, because I've been so proud of being "recovered" that I've been lying to myself. I've acted out on ED behaviors an increasing amount for the last two months  - more than I'm willing to admit. When I hadn't - for years. Had one or two slips, during really stressful moments, but that's it. Food is taking a bigger part of my life than it has for a long time. I have a therapist and nutritionist that I started seeing, ostensibly to clean up the lingering bits of my ED - but I'm afraid to tell them I'm struggling. Its complicated why, but I have a good reason for not disclosing to them. I don't think its a full relapse - but I'm on the edge. I'm hoping that this passes soon, and that its just a phase. Life is better without an ED - I know that. Its hard to remember that when times are tough, and I go to my first instinct - but its true.I just don't know what to do.  I think I just needed to own it, on here, to start with.

column9: Dear hermione3,It sounds like you have described some symptoms of a medical emergency. It is important that you seek medical attention immediately. Can you contact the doctor you are currently seeing? Another option is calling 911. In order to receive accurate treatment it is important to notify the medical staff that your symptoms could be related to your eating concerns.The following are just some of the signs of a serious problem that demands immediate medical attention: • accidentally or deliberately caused themselves a physical injury • become suicidal • confused thinking and is not making any sense • delusions (false beliefs) or hallucinations (experiencing things that aren’t there) • disoriented; doesn’t know what day it is, where they are or who they are • vomiting several times a day or has uncontrollable vomiting or diarrhea • experiencing dizziness or fainting spells • too weak to walk or collapses • painful muscle spasms • complaining of chest pain or having trouble breathing • blood in their bowel movements, urine or vomit • a body mass index (BMI) of less than 16 • an irregular heartbeat, and fast heartbeat, or very low heart beat (less than 50 beats per minute) • cold or clammy skin indicating a low body temperature or has a body temperature of less than 35 degrees Celsius/95 degrees Fahrenheit

column4: I Feel Like Im Suddenly Maintaining in My ED Recovery
column5: I've lost my urge to binge currently. I have been very focused on my 2 jobs and meal planning for my retail job feels very important to me.If I don't plan my Healthy Meals ahead of time then I found a pattern in needing to binge later at home in the evening.Since I'm on a balanced meal routine I have been doing quite well. I even purchased a pair of pants that fit me just right. I have had a few days off from my 2nd job but have been working almost daily at my primary job. It makes me feel good to work daily.Sometimes when i have extra time to myself i feel afraid of the future. My small apartment which i share w/ brother is affordable currently but I'm still anxious over the rates ever going up while we are here until i turn 50+ in a few yrs.Then I would like to find a place for middle-aged to older persons for a sense of peace and quiet and affordability. God,  I wish job # 1 would award me a raise for being a sub for at least 25 yrs in the public school system. A cost of Living Raise in the burbs of California, to be more specific. The people who earn the most tend to be the opposite. They have great medical coverage if they choose to have 12K taken out of their paychecks.

column5: Hi everyone,I’ve never posted in a forum, so I hope I’m doing this correctly. Anyway, I’m writing because I’m afraid I’m slipping back into restricting and other ED habits (so I guess I’m afraid I'm relapsing). I’ve been under a lot of stress lately, and I am also feeling incredibly uncomfortable in my body and with my eating habits. I have’t gained this much weight/gone this far in recovery since I began restricting in June, 2017. i’ve been in this episode of recovery for slightly over a month. I’m orthorexic and anorexic, so I’m highly afraid of sugar in addition to calories in general. Because I deprived myself of sugar (and processed food) for so long, I tend to crave those foods. This is my first time of recovery where I’ve allowed myself to eat sugary processed foods; other times I just increased my calorie intake. So, on Friday I ate a bunch of chocolate. I was so angry with myself and sad afterward, so I texted my nutritionist. She still hasn’t responded though. I feel like I’m just particularly needy in my recovery and an annoying patient that’s over reacting, so I keep telling myself not to contact my nutritionist or therapist. However, there’s another part of my brain that’s screaming at me to reach out because I’ve been letting myself skip snacks and eat smaller meals; I’ve also been restricting sugar and processed food, happier eating alone, and super tempted to count calories. I can’t decide what to do, and I feel so angry with myself any time I break my reemerging rules. I also feel so ashamed of myself because I feel like my nutritionist and therapist think I’m annoying/weak/someone who thinks they have a worse eating disorder than they do. Can anyone please help me figure out what to do? Thank you!

column4: How do I know when I've recovered from an eating disorder?
column5:
Hi everyone! I'm new here so sorry if I'm posting incorrectly.
I had been "dieting" for about 10 months before I realised I had really bad disordered eating, and I was getting all the symptoms of an eating disorder (no period, always cold, losing hair, always tired and irritable etc.) And I told myself that I needed to do something about it, so I decided to start "recovery". I'm doing it on my own as a specialist is too expensive, and it's been going on for about a month now. I think I'm doing well but I'm not sure. I've been forcing myself to eat and I've started to develop cravings and binge eating, but I'm telling myself this is necessary for full recovery so I'm just letting my body do its thing. I've regained so much energy and I'm starting to develop an appetite again. I feel like I'm already getting my hunger cues back, but once I eat I can't really stop and I have been snacking on so much chocolate until my stomach physically hurts. I feel much happier and I've started to sweat really bad at night and feel really tired towards the end of the day. I haven't regained my period again, but I did have blood and spotting last week. I have constipation and I feel really gassy and bloated all the time.
I reached an all-time low weight which was when I realised I needed to change, and I'm now at a weight which is healthy for my height. I'm not actually concerned about my weight as I'm just focusing on getting better, and I feel quite lucky that my disordered eating only went on for less than a year. But my question is how do I know when I've recovered from my eating disorder? I think I have developed a good relationship with food as I'm not constantly thinking about it and I let myself eat whatever I want without feeling guilty, and my symptoms seem like I'm pretty much recovered. The only problem is my binging and my inability to stop eating.

column5: So little back story here. I have battled low self esteem since elementary school, battled with eating disorders and exercise addiction since I was 16 years old, and I'm now 26. I have been doing very good for the last few years with only one relapse, and that was when I wanted to look extra amazing in my college graduation dress. I recently got engaged, to the best man in the world sorry ladies ;) and I always had a feeling that would trigger my ED. I was terrified to try on wedding dresses! Like I had a slight panic attack in the store before trying them on (not like me). I tried on quite a few and actually thought I looked amazing in every one of them and was so proud of how far I've come and that I could look in the mirror and love my body. Bought a very form fitting and comfortable dress and it's perfect. However, after I bought it my mind starting telling me, "But if you lost only like a few pounds it would look so much better!" And that's when the relapse started. I started "cutting carbs" which lead to only carbs from fruits and veg, and I started consuming alcohol (classis sign for me that I'm sick again), and scheduling extra workouts in. It lasted about 3 weeks and I was able to catch it, but man it sure messed me up. I feel like there is sooo much pressure to look your absolute best on your wedding day that it just got to me. A person who doesn't have a past like mine can easily want to lose a few pounds and it's ok, but for anyone with an ED past, I just dont know how that can work. Just curious if anyone else has triggers like these? And if so, any advice would be very appreciated! Above all, I want to be mentally healthy for my wedding day! I deserve it and so does my soon to be hubby ♡

column5: I've been recovered for about five years now. I always use the term recoverED instead of recoverING, because I thought my recovery was solid and unshakeable, and that I'd never go back to my ED. But for last few months I've had the ED thoughts start to creep back in. I dove right back into ED recovery circles and world, to try to get myself back out of that slump and remind me of the reasons I chose recovery, but my thoughts have just been getting worse. Lots of urges, lots of my old thoughts about my body that I thought I was over.  I think this is all because I'm at a major transition point in my life, and also because my body has changed lately. Changes are hard!But yesterday, for the first time in a very long time, I acted out on behaviors. It really freaked me out! I feel like such a hypocrite, because I actively work in eating disorder advocacy and treatment, and I am open about being RecoverED... but I had a slip-up. I know that one slip-up doesn't mean a relapse, but I am so scared of relapsing! And so scared of anyone knowing that I'm struggling. I thought I was doing so well, but I can't seem to turn off the thoughts.I'm not sure what to do - just thought I wanted to share this with others who might understand!

column5:
I've been holding off for a long time, but things just never seem to let up or get better.  It's getting harder and harder to deal with all the pain and stress.  I'm tired.  I'm just so tired.  I'm losing my ability to cope with the outside stress and my anxiety taking hold of everything and making it just that much worse.  I haven't been sleeping much, and I've been obsessing over every single detail of my life.  I panic if I can't figure out what I want to eat because I have options.  It gets to the point where I can't think straight.  I can't even read my homework sometimes because I'm so terrified I won't understand that the words on the page don't even look like words anymore.  Today, I just couldn't deal with all the panic and overwhelming situations my anxiety puts me in and self-harmed.  I feel so ashamed.  I feel like I'm letting everyone around me down.  I feel like I'm letting my therapist down.  That hurts so much.  I hate to see her disappointed or upset.  I want to make her happy.  I feel so weak, that I don't deserve her.  That I don't deserve anyone.  I'm not even upset that I did it to myself, just that I know it will make others sad.  I wish I could just disappear so I can never again be the cause of pain.  I just don't what to do, because all of me just wants this all to end, but life won't let me go.
I'm so sorry for this post.  I just feel so sad and so alone.  I just know you all understand...  I am safe tonight.  I am still here, still trying.  I just don't know why.
Julesthefox

column5: Hi, It might be a bit unfair to post on this forum as I don't feel I have an eating disorder so much. As I am underweight though, after loosing weight a few years ago, I'm also really trying to gain weight at the moment. I'm just a bit unsure what approach to have towards exercise with the weight I'm currently at. I've read really mixed things online - some completely advising against exercising until a healthy BMI is reached, just focusing on eating more, but others suggesting including regular exercise is a much healthier approach to take and will in fact help the process. Although I know it depends on the type of exercise. I know I would definitely like to begin incorporating more strengthening sessions (e.g. with weights) once I've gained a bit more weight so that I put on muscle as well as fat but I'm unsure when to begin this. I was thinking perhaps once I've put on some weight? At the moment though, other than walking, the only exercise I'm doing is yoga and cycling each week, as well as stretches each day. I'm unsure whether it might be sensible to do more exercise than this now though? And, if not, at what point it would be a good time to begin regularly doing weight and general strengthening exercises? Would hugely appreciate any advice! Thank you so much.

column4: 1 Year and still haven't recovered completely
column5: Hello! I'm a 20 year-old male who used to suffer from an eating disorder. 3.5 years ago, as I was a chubby teen, I started hitting the gym and eating clean. A few months in, I began monitoring my body image and the drastic change it underwent didn't passed unnoticed. I started obsessing about the purity of my daily meals, developing a mental disorder known as Orthorexia Nervosa. After a couple of months, my body image had gone from chubby to much more thin. I was very satisfied and determined to continue restricting food groups and calories until the side effects came up. My stomach started to bloat like a balloon nearly after every meal (no matter the quantity), my heart beat was very fast and intense (palpitations) and the most annoying...insomnia. I was so stressed because of it and I couldn't understand why it was happening to me (being in perfect shape and health with my so called perfect diet). Even though my body reacted like that, my mind stayed obsessed and I didn't change my eating habits right away. A few months after the appearance of these symptoms, I started eating more food but I was still restricting food groups and this kept on for about 2 years with my weight and image fluctuating from fit to underweight. However, the last summer while browsing the net I stumbled upon some articles and videos which made me realize: I wasn't on a special diet or plan which was ok because the calories were not deadly low. I had an eating disorder just as serious as anorexia nervosa in respect to the mental health part. Anyway, 1 year ago I began eating all kinds of foods and an adequate amount. I gained weight, but my symptoms haven't gone away completely. My difficulty to fall asleep has subsided, but my stomach still bloats very often and my heart beats crazy intensely after the majority of my meals. Is it normal to be like that after 1 year in recovery?  Should I gain more weight to help my body get over it? When will I recover completely?
column9: Hi Eat_everything, Your post was edited sligthly to remove numbers and detailed body descriptions, as these may be triggering for other forum members. Post guidelines can be found here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines. We hope you continue to post and find support on the forums.

column4: Wondering Why my Period is so Weird?
column5: 4 months ago It kind of froze on me. Then 2 months after the Big Freeze I had a weird experience, only lasted for a bit. Then 2 months again and no sign of period. I am experiencing the PMS symptoms though.I am bloated in the abdominal area, frequent urination, but do use medication for bloating too. Then I do experience cravings somewhat often. I give in slightly often too and use eating disorder behaviors.I feel like I am controlling my body, even in not having a real period anymore, and I am engaging in eating disorder behaviors, which I am feeling conflicted about.Unfortunately, I do have to work most evenings until 9 or 10 pm-is, so this prevents me from engaging in eating disorder behaviors, but I also struggle with trying to make up for it.   I gained a few lbs so am feeling extra anxious and it's causing me to engage in behaviors.  I feel guilty but can't help it.

column4: I am returning to my 2nd job soon...
column5: I am feeling anxious and excited for my vacation to be over this month, very soon. I will be returning to my teaching job mid-month, this month. I am also still employed at my PT retail job which has been great to me all summer providing me w/ at least 25-30 hrs per week in work hours. Unfortunately, retail work does not pay very well. But it has helped me to get through most of my summer. just when I was beginning to freak out over my financial situation my teaching job offered a few year-round job assignments at schools in session before the regular school year begins. I'm also on a list for a TA position in our district. If they offer me a job and its at a good school w/ decent co-workers and other TA's and teachers who work well as a team, and orient me into their classroom as a newbie on board, then I would love to work for that school as a new hire TA. Subbing pays more but TA position is usually only at 1 school w/ a regular staff and classroom do not change daily. This consistency is good. However, I enjoy sub teaching. I also have an interview coming up soon for a non-profit after hours, on-call job. I need to figure out how to even get to the interview site. An interview is scheduled for next week. It seems to be near a bus stop so may take a bus as we have a bus stop right in front of the new apartments where I now reside. I have been doing well w/, my Ed-0NOS ED atypical eating. Just a touch of orthorexia. I feel anxious about shopping for food. The price of food adds to my anxiety too. It seems as though the healthier the food I choose the more expensive it is. I also shop for my brother whenever I spot a sale of something he and I both may like to share for dinner. It is just the money part that I also associate w/ entering the grocery store that has begun making me extra anxious while on a Summer budget and now w/ new higher rent it is also a tad more anxiety producing.

column4: I don't know what to do
column5: Hi, I'm from Turkey and i'm currently maintaining recovery for my eating disorder. My therapist said what type of eating disorder i have but i can't find it in the internet. I'm also a lesbian and 4 months ago we broke up and i started to engage in behaviors. After that i couldn't eat and i've lost weight. I've started to go to a therapist about 2 months ago. I feel i recovered a little bit. But every time my girlfriend texts me i go back to ED behaviors again and start to feel hopeless and sad. After we broke up i talk to her again and we get back together. But my actions and feeling depressive was never gone. So i started to cut all my communication with her. But she keeps writing me back because she thinks we are on a break and i can't tell her that i wanna break up because i'm afraid that she reply angerly and say things that will hurt me. We don't have much choise in turkey about mental health care. So i wanted to share with you guys.

column5: I am recovering from an eating disorder that I just discovered I had less than a year ago.  I struggled with weight all my life.  I thought my father left (died) when I was 6yr old because I wasn't good enough.  Weighed a large amount by 10. Engaged in behaviors from ages 10-22, ruined vital parts of my body, didn't help with weight.  Lost a large amount of weight 7 years ago but working out a lot and not eating.  Last August got raped and brutally attacked by a friend.  Thought I didn't deserve food.  Got help was recovering.  Have a personal trainers who yell at me to eat.  Family is very supportive to have me eat but even with all the working out and such, still gaining weight.  REALLY want to stop eating again.  Was losing a lot every 2 weeks when I wasn't eating.  Really hard to resist.  The year anniversary of the attack is coming up, maybe that is a trigger.  But I don't feel right, I am going to break.

column5: Hi, I have been recovered from anorexia for 6 years but in the past year I have started to fall back into my old ways. My therapist has been working with me on it but I am becoming stubborn. My first slip up was after many people had commented on my weight gain from my medication. I began restricting and lost a reasonable amount of weight. My therapist began helping me with my day to day diet and it worked for a while. But lately I have felt an extreme loss of control. I lost my job and have suffered financially and my therapist who I am very attached to is going to be leaving in a month and I have to deal with the fact that I might never see her again after she's changed my life so much. On top of it I'm going to be transferring schools. These problems might not seem big but I feel like I'm losing everything I have. To cope I'm now obsessing over my weight desperate to lose "just a few more lbs." feeding my mind with pro ana nonsense and obsessively weighing myself. I want to be healthy and my therapist and my boss both told me that I'm heading down a very dangerous path. I don't want to be that person anymore but part of me is just so stubborn and is fighting me every step of the way. How can I talk myself out of this?

column4: What are helpful tools you use to overcome the urge to weigh yourself?
column5: I had my husband get rid of our scale per my therapist’s suggestion and my desire to do whatever it takes to beat Ed for good. The first week and a half I was eating intuitively and feeling like a recovery rockstar. Until today. Ed is so loud and all consuming. Not having the scale is definitely one of his biggest tools for keeping me in his grip. I notice my clothes fitting snug and with that, fears set in and my desire to control and obsession to know my weight resurface. I understand this is Ed, not me. I am reaching out for suggestions on tools you guys use to cope with clothes fitting tighter and the anxiety the valleys of recovery brings. Hugs and well wishes to you all!

column5:
Hello! I have had an eating disorder since I was 17 (I'm now 20, about to turn 21 next week.) Something that is a huge stumbling block in recovery is the fact I am prone to panic attacks after eating. This usually occurs if I eat a little more than I'm used to, for example in a restaurant, because fullness is somewhat of a trigger. It triggers me to use various kinds of eating disorder behaviors. Sometimes I get panic attacks if I haven't exercised that particular day, or even if my eating pattern has been normal and frankly it's so debilitating. Recovery is like a full time job, except you don't get paid for it and when this thing keeps happening it feels like such a kick in the teeth. It's soul destroying at times to have done all his hard work to be triggered into a panic attack by the one thing we need to keep us alive. Can anyone relate? Does anyone have any advice? You have no idea how much I'd appreciate it! <3 Big love to everyone,
Elle xo
