For your reference, guidelines are available here:  https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines. We hope you continue to post and find support here!

column4: Developing ED, traveling to europe, scared of gaining weight.
column5:
Hi there. I wasn't diagnosed yet but I feel like I have some symptoms of a developing ED.To sum it up, I was chubby and got bullied by family and ex boyfriend in the past, so I became into fitness, lost weight and started working out, which I really enjoy.
But lately I feel like things are out of control. I can only feel guilty everytime I eat something that's not in my meal plan (I go to a dietitian who helps me gain muscle and maintain body fat at lean levels). I am extremely scared of gaining fat, keep dreaming about food, I'm feeling detached from my current boyfriend, avoiding partying so I don't have alcohol, I'm moody all the time and being a pain in the a** to people around me, working out A LOT more than before, etc... I am obssessing over my shape all the time.The thing is:I'm going to Europe next week with my boyfriend. We saved for this trip for years in advance and I was really excited about this life experience with the person I want to marry someday! We'll be spending 18 days in the Netherlands, Belgium and Ireland.And all I can think about is: gonna get fat from trying wonderful, typical local foods and not working out once (the hotels don't have gyms, I'm just walking)I'm overthinking this trip a lot and getting really anxious. Everyone say I should relax and accept a potential slight weight gain, saying I can lose it back in no time when I come home. Life experiences are unique and I don't get to travel much (once every 6 years or so, I almost never went abroad). I thought about 2 different approaches: either I will restrict myself, only eat clean foods and be in my "safe ED zone" or I will enjoy what I want, have mostly healthy, real-food meals and also let myself drink beer with my bf, try desserts and different foods I don't have at home.Do you guys think I should LET GO of those thoughts and force myself to eat whatever I want, even though I gain some weight, just to reset my mind and keep this iminent ED from totally taking control of my life? I feel like traveling is, somehow, a possibility to go out of my comfort zone and see how bigger the world really is, how much there is out there to be enjoyed and also how great it would be to strenght my relationship. I feel like if I actually gained weight, I would force myself to get used to that and love my body anyways. I feel like I need to enjoy the trip at max and win this mental game I tricked myself into!Thoughts? Anyone been on a trip? What did you do?

column5: Hey guys, I'm Mia and I have been struggling with disordered eating for a little over 1 year. I lost my period in August of last year and even though I have gained weight (mainly muscle) it hasn't come back. Through reading I've understood that it probably won't come back unless I take a break from exercise, regardelss of if I'm eating enough. This Friday I made a huge mental break through and was able to commence my recovery. I have had a weekend of eating any and everything I want and not exercising at all! I feel liberated but at the same time very, very frightened. The thoughts of calculating food, going for a run or to the gym are constently in my head. I'm trying to do this on my own and wanted to ask what and how much you guys are eating in recovry? Like I said, this weekend was a free-for-all but I also ate "real" food along with the other stuff. How do you know if you are eating enough?

column5: Had a really rough therapy session today basically saw my nutritionist full well knowing i probably lost weight because I have not been eating well due to my stomach issues but she told me to tell the truth i have just been running with this as an excuse. My therapist was very not happy with me and asked how she can even trust me about this stuff because i told her some other things recently i had been keeping from her and stuff and she said I need to work harder. I know she is right i do need to work harder. i said i would volunteer as a big brother big sister she said that is great but I have to be taking care of myself to be able to truly give to someone else. we talked about me living alone and she said its close to being be hospitalized and then have to live with my parents because how long do i think she will let me be chronically suicidal and depressed and live alone. it was just hard then she called me on my way home she just talked to my best friends mom who died about 3 years ago now and her mom was very sad and missing my friend and my therapist told me people care do you want them to be sad about you on a nice June day just think about it and i was like going to cry so just said ok...its just been an emotional day...

column5: I just don't know how to beat this. I'm maintaining life, but I'm still ruled by food, I still count calories, and am very often incredibly anxious about my weight. It makes me so obsessive. The trouble is I don't think I realize how ruled by ED I still am. I keep convincing myself it's okay. this is enough. you're alive. I really need some inspiration.

column4: Stuck in a complicated not recovered place.
column5: Oh boy so this is one heck of a place for me to be in. So I had active anorexia for 4 years, and was put into the only clinic in my area which was, to put it gently, garbage. I was given no emotional support for my recovery, put on medication on the first day, and then later given a medication that contributed to almost all of my weight gain. I increased my overall intake, but not to normal and not nearly enough for recovery. The trauma of the clinic sent me back into dissociation (which was my default coping mechanism for other traumas as well), so not only did I barely increase my intake, but I coped by blocking out all feeling. So here I am. It's been almost 3 years and essentially I'm at the same place I was before. The old feelings and realization of my habits are coming back. I know I can't keep this up forever. But right now the fear of gaining more weight is beating the fear of being like this forever. It sounds horrible, but I almost wish I could go back to how I was so I could feel less disgusting about gaining more weight. I miss my old body. and I need help.

I have previously been through 2 IVF's which has really caused me to gain a lot of weight. I never have been at my current weight and it worries me. I hate my body. I hate the way i look. My husband say oh your hot. but i just don't see it.Empty silence

column5: Hello, I know this is a very minor problem, but it has been making me very depressed lately and making me not want to eat ... well, even less than I usually want to.I'm a little over a month into full-blown recovery and in the past couple of weeks food has just not tasted good to me at all. I'm never hungry or desiring food as my hunger cues are not restored. This really bothers me because before my ed I was quite a "foodie" and food was one of my favorite parts of life. And then during my disorder it tasted even better because I was restricting it so much. But now that I am back to eating normally I just can't seem to enjoy any foods, even old favorites or exciting new things that I had not previously allowed myself. Eating has become such a chore and I just feel sick of all food.I just wanted to know if anyone else has experienced this and anything that may help? Thank you for any advice :)

column5: I have been struggling and talked today to my therapist about my brother and his abuse and how i was looking through my phone and i was looking at old texts with him just because and i asked my therapist if i should feel bad that he has lost everything since the whole drama of being under investigation for his crimes and then me coming out about my own abuse. About a year ago my parents had my brother move to Florida and that is when i tried to talk to them about his abuse to me and how i felt he was getting off free to move to Florida with my grandpa. My mom asked me i wanted him to kill himself i said no of course not.when the cops went to his work to get his tablet he ran and went missing and in that time he tried to kill himself and i told my therapist i sort of had wished he died....my parents were mad about how i found out about his being moved my therapist told me after they told her they were going to wait to tell me but my therapist doesn't believe in keeping secrets from me so she told me. My parents I guess told her they were upset with how she handled it or something and also asked her if she wanted my brother to die and she stopped responding to them because she couldn't respond to it not emotionally. she also said i am her patient and my well being is more important to her then my brother... I had texted her about how I also want to die most of the time and i said my parents should look at who in part caused that like they were concerned with that rather then hearing out how i felt. my therapist also agreed and was like yea and they were worried he would kill himself after watching you try to kill yourself for years...and to be honest most of the time still want to die...i dont' wish harm on him i really don't but he caused me a lot of pain

Other resources through NEDA for someone to talk to include: Helpline 1-800-931-2237 Chat at www.myneda.org Text "NEDA" to 741741Please keep posting!

column5:
So I am absolutely doing amazing. I stopped obsessively weighing myself. I am consistently over a healthy amount of calories. I woke up one day and made my own recovery plan with my own calorie goal benchmarks each week. I have had so much success in two weeks that I’ve amazed even myself. But.
Going through ana recovery without any support is brutal sometimes. I have to say that quitting smoking was easier.
There are times that I think the reason why I’m successful this time is because I don’t have a super loud cheering squad. There are other times I get so angry that I don’t get cheered on and celebrated by husband for overcoming really hard milestones for me. Then I think to myself, “come on, you’re a grown ass women...you shouldn’t need a party every time you do something that’s hard for you”.
I was at my max calorie amount and my husband wanted a movie night which means a lot of candy and sugary drinks. I still stayed up and vegged out with him- that was huge for me. I didn’t restrict myself the next day or have a mental breakdown. I gained weight and I completely stunned myself by not even caring.
I know it’s stupid but I’m so angry at him for not realizing how huge that was for me and just how hard it was to eat all that extra junk food knowing I was crossing my calorie limit. After so many fights in the past being centred around ana you’d think he’d be my #1 fan but he isn’t...he has flat out told me that he doesn’t care anymore or want to hear about how much I’ve gained or how many calories I eat. I’m doing the hardest thing I’ve ever done and he doesn’t care....

column4: Death of someone close to me
column5: I am having a hard week a parent of one of my students died and I was close to her as parents of my students goes I mean we would talk for half an hour when she picked up her daughter. She was only 37 and we don't know exactly jos she died just in her sleep but I am just so sad for her children my student well she is not in my class anymore but she is 3 and her brother is 6 just so young and my heart just breaks for them she just was the type person who made an impact on you that is what me and the other teachers who knew her agree she was just wonderful and you could just tell how much she loved her kids they were her world. We asked her husband who is also wonderful how the kids are and my students brother who is 6 he said was very upset at first but doing better now and well my student who is only 3 doesn't understand and is asking for her mom.i went to the wake yesterday and it was open casket and I was just so sad it didn't look like her like I don't want that image in my mind. I went to the funeral today and it was just sad I just feel so many things I feel I could burst it's just like why her I have already been slipping back and having suicidal thoughts and it's like this just does not help my emotional state but I have to just think how many people went to this wake the people she touched I keep thinking I have dove so much to hurt myself and should be dead by now why not me my therapist said there must be a purpose for me. Sorry this is long just so sad could use some support.

column5: Hi hope you can help me... I’ve been recovering since November 2017 when I got impatient because I was doing quite bad; I had bradycardia and a very low BMI but then I started gaining weight and I felt much better but last week I got off of my meal plan and I don’t feel so good about my BMI because I think I’m starting to lose weight... The worst part is I’m not feeling hungry like at all... I don’t... it’s terrible and my current BMI is lower than my set point weight or something like that... So yeah I’m a little bit scared and I don’t know what to do because I have a high calorie meal plan and and right now I’m trying to eat whatever I want to, no restrictions but the thing is I’m so full and I’m not willing to eat anymore I’m just satiated I don’t know what to do... by the way I am 17 years old and I’m a male and I don’t know if that has anything to do... Thank you very much for your help in advance.

column4: Comments from the public& struggle with recovery
column5:
Hello everybody,
This is my first post and I am quite nervous and hope everything I am writing is appropriate.
I have been in recovery for 1 year and 3 months now, I had a relapse 7 months after first attempting recovery, but have been good ever since. In my past I had issues with over exercising and bulimia. I was never underweight and probably in the lower healthy weight range. Due to recovery I have now gained some weight, which put me in the overweight range. I am struggling to find a balance with my eating, some days are better, some days are worse. Which really scares me that since I've gained all this weight, my blood lipid levels have worsened and I've developed arthritis in my knees, making it impossible for me to do the high intensity exercise I relied on earlier in times I needed this extra endorphine kick and to "keep me in shape". I am very unhappy with how my body looks and feels and am not able to accept it the way it is now. I was never overweight, and a very skinny child. My family is quite averse to weight gain and I am studying a nutrition related degree. I feel like I am being judged by friends and strangers, the other day I was even being asked about my weight gain in a very insensitive way. This really has triggered feelings from the past. I am quite uncertain on how to proceed, I don't think I can/ want to accept my current body, as it is obviously putting me at risk of other health issues and I am basically withdrawing myself from all social events and even friends. On the other hand I don't want to fall back into old behaviours. I am hardly engaging in any social activities any more, don't like to dress nicely and am basically isolating myself from events which require to dress up and look nice. I feel like I am in a vicious cycle, which I don't know how to escape anymore... has anyone else experienced similar feelings? I had a psychiatrist for a while, which led me on the way to recovery. I am now unable to afford her, and am left with so many questions... Advice would be highly appreciated! x

column5:
Hi, I just felt as if I needed to share because I've been really struggling emotionally lately.
I am currently in recovery for anorexia, depression, and anxiety and have been for around half a year. Recovery was really important to me, but lately it seems only as if food served as a comfort rather than a fear.
Daily I have been engaging in eating disorder behaviors and I feel horribly about it. There are occasional times in which I will attempt other eating disorder behaviors, but none of my attempts have been successful. After checking my weight at a doctor's appointment a few days ago, I found that I gained slight weight, which really shocked and irritated me (which truthfully was to my surprise- I had thought body image wasn't as much of an issue to me).
Additionally, my sister is demonstrating very anorexia-like symptoms, which really scares me.
Self harm has been a coping strategy for me in the past, and I have recently picked up self harm again, but have been very closely watched ever since my parents found out, so I feel as if I cannot release everything I am feeling.
To summarize, restricting is a really appealing thought to me at this point, but I fear demonstrating poor eating habits in front of my sister. Does anyone have any suggestions on these kind of recovery thoughts?

column5:
Addiction affects more than one would expect, in different ways and forms.  No one experience is like another, which is why my intentions with this paper are what they are.  Ideally, with the submission of this to forums, I am raising awareness and sharing my story to others who need support and to feel they are not alone.  My experience with addiction started in high school and took many different turns throughout the years, still following me daily.  I am aware of what I have been through, and I am strong enough to listen to it, feel it, and rise above it.  I, along with the help of family, friends, and medical professionals, have been provided with the tools to conquer.  It is important to remember that addiction does not discriminate.  No matter who you are, what you do, or what you come from, this disease will sneak its way into your life.
	I was introduced to this realm sophomore year of high school but I wasn’t wise or aware enough to recognize how broad the world of addiction is.  I was diagnosed with an eating disorder, which contrary to popular belief is an addiction.  I became obsessed with, more so addicted, to control.  It was tiring, sickening, and affected not only me but also the ones around me.  This started all around the time my parents were going through a divorce, surrounding me with constant arguments and changes in my life.  The only thing that was stable in my life was school, the gym, and rowing, all having to be sacrificed for my eating disorder.  I was consumed with numbers.  It became all I cared about.  My relationships fell apart because I put no effort into saving them; I only cared about losing weight.  My family was fed up with me; I was setting a poor example for my three younger sisters.  My eating disorder spoke to me, telling me they were just jealous I was losing weight, but also telling me I needed to stay on target and starve myself.  I had no energy to be a good person, sister, or daughter.  When outpatient therapy wasn’t enough, my parents admitted me into inpatient therapy.  It was extremely frustrating because I missed in total five weeks of school being admitted twice.  My first round was very rough, I hated being told what to eat and what to do, share my feelings and experiences with strangers who didn’t understand me.  I was very resistant to help but realized that I could fake it until I made it, which is just what I did.  It didn’t work out for me though, because two months after I was sent right back.  I did it right that time; being open to what I was exposed to.  I saw elderly people who let their eating disorder control their whole life, realizing that this is not what I wanted to live with.  It was weird because I truly loved my eating disorder because it gave me the tools to be a better (looking) person, but I also hated what it had done to my life.   My eating disorder took away a lot from me; I wasn’t allowed to stay on the rowing team, I missed school, and I was constantly fighting with my parents.  I consider myself now recovered, even though I still hear the voices in my head every day.  I have been provided with the tools to silence those voices, and I never deprive myself anymore.  I was able to work with my school to ensure my grades stayed where I wanted them, and despite the odds, was able to graduate early.  My relationship with my family is stronger than ever, and I am proud to say I have become a positive role model for my sisters.
	Senior year of high school I was prescribed medication for severe anxiety “as needed.”  By the time I was a freshman in college, I had become very dependent on these pills.  I was very lonely; I had no friends and was extremely homesick.  I took the medication on a regular basis, when I thought I “needed” it.  Two months into my first semester, I started having seizures that gradually got worse.  No one knew what it was from and I had no medical history of epilepsy.  Ten seizures, all on the URI campus; I was so confused and scared.  I ended my freshman year early, on April 1st, the day I knocked out three teeth in a horrible grand mal seizure.  I was then admitted into the hospital for testing and monitoring my episodes.  I had no seizures during my stay, and they adjusted and kept me on the medication.  It took another seizure to understand that I was experiencing withdrawals from when I would take the medication.  I had no idea I was addicted to it; I would’ve never expected myself to be addicted to a pill or anything for that matter.  Once I got off the pills, my health was stable and restored.
	If that wasn’t enough, a few months later my younger sister, who was 17 at the time, began using drugs.  For a while she hid it very effectively, but her life started to crash around her and all of us.  No one understood what she was going through or why she couldn’t just stop.  It was exceedingly tedious and agonizing to watch her cry in a mental hospital begging us to take her home.  I wasn’t able to handle balancing the stress and school, and spent all my free time driving to whichever hospital she was at the time.  My grades started dropping, and I left school for a semester to focus on her and my own mental health.  Months went by, and she made a remarkable recovery.  Everything started falling back into place for the first time in years.  She is now on the Deans List at her university and excelling at everything she does, all while maintaining her sobriety.
	Every encounter with addiction is different, and they all have their own distinct qualities.  However, all benefit from one thing: support.  Ideally, this paper will touch others who have experienced similar happenings.  My journey from self-destruction to self-realization has been a rough one, but I’ve learnt so much about myself from it.  I have risen above, despite the bumps in the road along the way.  I have betrayed myself along with having been betrayed by others.  I was tricked into driving one of my best friends to get drugs, only realizing it shortly after when he was overdosing in my car.  I’ve had to distance myself and remove myself from relationships, but I have also reinforced and created new healthy relationships.  I am content where my life is now.
	To those reading this, you are never alone.  I hope my words can reach out and touch those who need support.  There is a light at the end of the tunnel and once you find it, it’s incredible.  I would not be who I am now if I had not gone through my journey with addiction, and I believe that I am a stronger person because of it.

column5:
This is my first time posting here. I would like to share about myself and I am wondering if I am alone in some of these things. I am on a road to recovery. However, my recovery is from a lot more than an eating disorder. In fact this is the first time I am talking about my eating issues honestly. I am seeking support and help for the first time for my struggles with food, body image, and extreme emotions/behaviors. I am a survivor of child abuse, domestic violence, and rape. I am a single mom to a preschooler. I work two jobs and I am a full time student. I live an extremely stressful life. It has been just over two years since I left my abusive situation and began the road to recovery from a lifetime of abuse. I am in a safe place now and I am receiving help from d.v. and rape crisis center as well as therapy for ptsd. But my eating has been triggered...badly!
I have never officially been diagnosed with an eating disorder even though I have struggled with this since I was very young. It got really bad around the age of 13 and I have been on a roller coaster of self-destructive eating behaviors for 17 years now. I have been good at hiding my issues. But after everything I have faced and overcome, I am ready to face this now too. My biggest problem is that I don't know how define the disorder that I have. I don't know if I fit into a category. I feel alone.
From the time I was very young (around 8 yo) I had a problem with "emotional eating." Food was used as a weapon in our home. It was either withheld or forced on us in copious amounts. I began dealing with being overweight and teased when I was in second grade. When I hit middle school the starvation began. The feeling of hunger did not bother me because I was accustomed to it. I would go weeks and sometimes months without eating or barely taking bites of vegetables. During these phases I would also exercise to excess. I could not and would not eat anything pleasurable. I did this for the same reason I always do when I am on a starvation kick. If I taste of food that I find satiating it initiates a feeding frenzy that I cannot control. I am like a shark who has tasted blood and I have no ability to stop myself. The problem is that sometimes a binge for me can also go on for weeks or months at a time. I struggle to reign my self back in. When I do gain control I go back to starvation. I am never in the middle eating a balanced or healthy amount of food. This is far more extreme than the yo-yo dieting I have always joked that I have. My weight fluctuations are dramatic and have done a lot of damage to my body (including high cortisol levels and a slowed metabolism). I struggle with my weight and self image to the point where I avoid seeing people I know in public because I do not want them to see my weight. This happens at both ends of the spectrum. I am never satisfied with my body and I am always ashamed about my eating whether its too little or too much.
Currently I am stuck in a binge that I cannot control and I am at my breaking point. The binge started right before thanksgiving. I have put on considerable weight in 4 months because I just cannot stop this frenzy. I am unhappy with myself and extremely tempted to go into starvation mode. But my health is suffering and I don't want to repeat this cycle anymore. What is this disorder? Its confusing lonely and scary.
Does anyone else get stuck in a binge like this? Does anyone else have similar struggles?

column4: Discharge from residential, directly to outpatient
column5: Hi! I'm new here but wanted to see if anyone has had a similar experience. I was discharged from residential treatment a week and a half ago after two months. I weight restored and was in a much better place and felt ready to move on. However, when I returned home I found out that the discharge plan that my insurance created for me didn't actually exist. Since then, I've been bounced around between outpatient programs. I haven't had any appointments besides initial intakes with therapists I never see again. I refused my insurance IOP program originally after spending three months there spiraling before I was referred to residential. The IOP team agrees that their consequence-based method does not work for me (if I did not finish a meal in under 30 minutes I was not allowed to stay for group) and will not accept me back. I have three locations through my insurance that are all recommending I go to one of the others and none of them are communicating. I am advocating for myself and trying to get to an appropriate level of care, but I'm continuously being told outpatient treatment with therapy, dietician, and medical appointments once every three weeks is my only option. The best place for me right now would be PHP or an out-of-network IOP, but my insurance refuses to cover those. The shift from 24/7 support to absolutely nothing has been incredibly overwhelming and I am already relapsing. Every day without treatment the ED voice gets a little louder and I use more behaviors. I am so frustrated and tired of fighting, and I feel like giving up and letting the eating disorder take over so that maybe they'll be more willing to help. I feel like I am expected to do the rest on my own and I'm embarrassed that two months in residential wasn't enough for me to become completely self-reliant. Does anyone have any advice for dealing with insurance in general? Has anyone successfully made the transition straight from residential to outpatient? Thanks!
column9: Hi izzypizzy! Welcome to the forums! Your post was edited slightly because it contained a specific mention to an insurance carrier. Please refer to our Community Guidelines (https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines), and continue to post!

column5: I've never posted here before but I seem to be having a tough night. I've been in recovery for some years and overall doing fairly well but I have been struggling.  I don't think any of this is triggering but if it is please let me know and I will delete - I am not sure what is and isn't considered not okay to post.So I was married last fall. My husband is wonderful, he knows about my disorder and while he doesn't always know what to do or how to help he always tries.  A couple years ago I was diagnosed with Hashimoto's (a hypothyroid disorder).  I've since gained weight and it's much more difficult to healthily control it.  Tonight I found myself looking at pictures from the wedding and I'm getting very anxious because I don't like how I look.  I had bought my dress too early before I was diagnosed and when I look at myself when it came in and then when the wedding was I am really unhappy with how I look.  I don't really know what I'm looking for.  I think I just needed to get this feeling out there somewhere people would understand how I'm feeling and not try to placate meor try to avoid talking about it because they don't know what to say.  It was an amazing day and I'm so happy to be married but I continue to struggle now with how I look as I try to regulate my hormones and feeling so unhappy with how I looked then is really hitting me hard today.Sorry if this was against guidelines - I'm not sure... thank you
column9: Hi Makome,Welcome to the forums! Please reference our guidelines for future posts: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelinesAlso, feel free to contact our helpline (M-TH 9-9 EST / F 9-5) 800 - 931 - 2237 or text NEDA to 741 741.We hope you continue to post!

column5:
I have struggled with Anorexia for the last 8 years of my life. There are so many factors, both as a result of "nature and nurture" causes, that I developed my ED I believe, and after awhile I have come to realize that it doesn't really matter what began my ED, rather, what I choose to do now in the midst of my struggle that counts. I will never be able to truly move forward in the recovery process if I continue to analyze and dissect the past, remaining stuck in the "should'ves and could'ves."
One of my greatest battles I fight now is to get to, and maintain, a healthy BMI, and not just "walk the line"/"live on the edge of a knife" as my mom calls it. I am happily married and on the outside my life is truly blessed, yet, I keep engaging in eating disorder behaviors and continue to live in fear of my past returning.
I have been through treatment several times, found great healing and support and a new identity, maintain good medication with a good Psychiatrist and have access to resources at a local outpatient treatment facility. But, I am hesitant to dive back in to continual sessions with my Therapist and Dietitian due to my schedule, feeling "safe" where I am at and I have to admit, apprehensive about my Dietitian taking full control of my meal plan again.
As my mom puts it, I am "Living on the Edge"; in recovery, doing amazingly well overall, but still holding on to dangerous parts of my ED which keeps me from living a full life holistically. Any advice and tips?
column9: We had to delete several of your posts.Recovery rockstar: The forum cannot be used to promote a specific treatment approach or facility, as what works for one person may not for another. Iwanttolive: While we are glad your religion has helped you on your recovery journey, heavily promoting personal religious beliefs to others is not appropriate.We hope you understand this situation and continue to post on these forums. You can read our community guidelines here: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines

column4: Missing Work and Hate Feeling Powerless over My Body
column5: Im currently going through pre-menapause and No I have NOT STOPPED having my periods YET.....I've been on my period for the last 1.5 weeks and just want to go to work, or shop, or walk as usual at night when I am working during the day to keep busy as well as to pay thee house bills to keep things going in my life.The problem is that just when I thought it was safe to get dressed and go to work I realize that mother nature had a different plan for me.I have been experiencing super heavy, non stop menstrual period for the last 6 days of this 1.5 week of menses.First I suffered food poisoning after handling chicken, and biting my nails or doing something nervously stupid of the sort.Then was shocked to find my wallet missing from my purse where I ALWAYS keep it, in my room.Then had to run all around and replace my ID items after all that and call credit bureau to put a lock on my identity as well. Just when I was Finally able to relax a tad and return to work, my period arrives and stays way past it's Welcome Time. Now it wont leave and I feel imprisoned by my period. I was supposed to go to work today and I cant. I obviously lost my appetite over this Trauma just as I regained it after the 1st trauma of the flu and a stolen wallet.I just want to go dig a hole in the yard and go hide in IT-Or invent a robot that seeks out thieves from the point of home invasion to the point of Wallet Recovery, or whatever is stolen...?I miss not feeling free to jump into my car and go buy some food that I enjoy eating and eat it. I miss not being able to go to work for the day and come home and be able to take a nice refreshing walk as I de-stress and get in my exercise for the day too.God when am I going to return to "Normal" again???  I can't accept this level of misery and unpredictability I am experiencing currently.....
column9: Hi chunkymonkey68! We slightly edited your post. We hope you continue to seek support and post about how this problem is affecting your recovery. Best wishes!

column4: Nerve pain triggered in ED recovery phase
column5: Hi there,I'm reaching out to see if anyone has had problems with pain/neuropathy that was only triggered *after* recovery.I had orthorexia for four years - restricted during the week, and binge ate/drank over weekends. I never struggled with any form of physical pain or discomfort during the ED, and was extremely active. I didn't have muscle atrophy, and although I was underweight, I looked fit and had good muscle tone. In November last year, I took the decision to quit my ED cold turkey, before getting married. I didn't go via a dietitian or counsellor. I started eating everything in sight, in an effort to gain weight. The biggest change, apart from the quantities, was going from a very lean diet, to an extremely carb-heavy diet. After about 10 days, I started to develop nerve pain in my feet, which has now travelled all the way up my legs, and even into my hands and face. I also get terrible cramp-like sensations, which are worsened with activity. I have been unable to exercise since then, and the problem only seems to be spreading. I currently have a diagnosis of idiopathic peripheral neuropathy. Once again, I want to emphasise that this is not a result of malnutrition, as it began very clearly and distinctly during my recovery phase, and not before. I have searched for everything under the sun, but have found nothing that clearly links ED recovery with neuropathy (although long-term malnutrition does cause neuropathy). I have been for blood tests and MRIs, and nothing is abnormal. So far, the only explanation that doctors can give me, is that it might be an autoimmune response (e.g. an acquired dietary intolerance, even though I did eat all food groups during my ED - just in limited quantities).Any help, guidance or advice would be appreciated. This has become a literal disability, and I am unable to do all the things I would normally do.

column5:
After abusing laxatives for 5 years and multiple self-recovery attempts, all failing after a few days of terrifying refeeding edema...I am finally seriously moving forward with my self-recovery and over looking my scary edema body for the sake of achieving a happier, less depressed and anxiety driven existence.
Anyways, I am trying to figure out this edema thing.  I have read enough now to understand and accept why it's happening, but I can't seem to find any information on how it goes away, and what I should be seeing after almost 2 weeks of severe water retention.
I am on my 11th laxative-free/crazy edema body day, and I am experiencing some watery stools.
This worries me due to my past laxative abuse, and yet, how else is the water retention going to go away?
I just want to know whether I should be expecting watery stools as my edema goes away, or if it's something to worry about?
Also, I've only had edema for 11+ days...I have read that others experience it for months and even YEARS (so scary)...is my edema possibly going away too soon because I'm doing something wrong?
I am eating tons of food/calories, although it is all extremely healthy and very fibrous.
I can't go to a doctor because I don't have insurance and I'm broke living in San Francisco haha, and I hate going to a doctor anyway...so if anyone has some knowledge on refeeding edema, or could share their experience with it, I would greatly appreciate it!
Thank you for your support!
column9: I made some minor edits to your posts to remove numbers or particular phrases or words that might be triggering to others. Guidelines are here if anyone needs a refresher: https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines. Thanks for posting.

column5:
Hi. I need some advice.  My Mom wants me to go to the gym with her for strenghtening my very weak body.  But I don't want to go as I find it difficult to see the various types of bodies. She only wants what is best for me but I don't feel strong enough to tell her I don't want to go .   I hurt days after I go.   The other thing is my day program. I don't like it and get nothing out of going.  I don't even want to finish the week.  I have two therapists lined up to interview.  I again feel I have no choice.  Very co dependent on both sides,  Mom and me.   Any advice?
            iwanttolive My mom helps me with so much and I feel I owe it to her to do everything she suggests.  I sincerely don't know what to do.   I am fifty but because I am so dependet on everything my parent's tell me to do or suggest, I feel stuck and not able to make a decision for myself.  I would appreciate any insight into this.  Thank you.                                                       iwanttolive
column9: Hi iwanttolive, Your post has been edited a bit. Please refrain from mentioning body types in the forums. Thank you and please continue posting!

column4: it's a choice and acceptance for me
column5:
Hi friends,I am in a place where I have to choose to accept my body even though it is at a weight I do not like.  For me it is a choice now.  I can be mad or disgusted or shamed, but I must choose acceptance.   I just turned fifty,  I rarely engage in eating disorder behaviors.  Going close shopping is difficult, but I do not want to allow what I look like to rule my moods and the way I feel about myself.  I am me, and I will still be me even at a higher weight.  Easy? No.  But necessary to continue on my journey of recovery.   I have been free from self harm thoughts and actions for about three weeks now and I will continue on in that vain.  I am pursuing health and a healthy mind.  It takes work.  I have to say when I start thinking badly, NO, it won't change anything if I do this or that.  So, I am back on track and even though I miss my old body, and the "sick" look, I want to be well..  I don't want the sick look.  I want to shine for Jesus.  To shine to help others.  To shine so I can go to Nigeria.   I hope this helps someone out there.   I really care about you all.  Take care,
                                                                              iwanttolive
column9: Hi iwanttolive,Your post has been edited. Please refrain from sharing ED behaviors on the forum, as we do not want to trigger anyone.

column4: Anyone take appetite-stimulating medicine for years?
column5: A few months ago my family doctor prescribed a medication to help boost my appetite.  I love this medicine and I take a very small dose.My question is, are there people who take these kinds of medicine for years in order to help them be able to eat?  Is that common/normal?   The therapist I'm seeing thinks that the reason I don't enjoy eating has to do with childhood experiences.  I'm alright seeing her for a good while to see if therapy helps.  But I'm also enjoying the effects of this medicine and thinking "can't this just be my solution?"  Because it makes such a difference, and it DOES help.  And I have never wanted to be thin or worried about what my body looked like or anything.  It's just that I just don't enjoy eating very much, and am frequently too nervous to eat.  Just wondering if anyone stays on meds of this sort for years.
column9: Hi Elara. Welcome to the forums! Your post was edited slightly because it contained specific wording that may be triggering to our other forum members. Please refer to our Community Guidelines (https://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/forums/community-guidelines), and continue to post!

column4: Will I ever stop gaining weight?
column5: I restricted food/dieted and binged for over 15 years. I began recovery in June of this year. I stopped my outpatient treatment in November because I felt I was at a point in my recovery where I could. Things are going well except that I still feel distressed over my weight gain sometimes. I have gained weight since I started recovery in June. I am scared it will never stop, let alone go down. Through the entire course of my ED I was “overweight”. Now I am “obese”. My mentality towards fat and fat phobia has changed enough that I have been able to recover and I understand that I am looking at years for my weight to stabilize. It’s hard when most resources talk about weight gain in anorexia recovery or even weight loss in binge eating recovery, but I was never either of those. I don’t know what is going to happen. Shouldn’t this stop at some point? And even go the other direction? Is there anyone else out there like me?
column9: dmack24, Thank you so much for posting on the NEDA forums.  We just would like to remind to keep numbers out of the forums.  You can check out our community guidelines if you would like to check out the forum rules! Thank you!
column13: Hi ChunkyMonkey68, Your post was edited slightly to remove mention of specific exercise habits and results. Thank you for being a source of support in this community, and please continute to find and give support on the forums!

column4: How do you deal with other people triggering you?
column5: I've been dealing with an eating disorder (anorexia) since I was 12, now I am 19. I'm 1 month and 3 days in and I'm loving every second, I feel like I'm really freeing myself of this sick mindset I used to maintain for years. It feels so free. I get scared and anxious a lot but I keep going. I have no other option if I want to be happy and in peace.But even my loved ones keep saying things that sound disordered like comments about what they eat and how it makes them feel guilty after indulging. It makes me feel really bad. My chest gets tight and I feel a strong anxiety rising. I've been meditating for roughly 2.5  months now so sometimes I'm glad I have the chance to deal with the anxiety that rises in such situations, let myself feel it and try to not engage with any bad thoughts that may arise from me or try to ease the anxiety by engaging in ED behavior. But I just wish people would understand, they hurt me so much and they don't even realize it.How do you people deal with it? Do you experience such things in a regular basis?I know what I have to do but I want to hear from people who really understand what this is like.
column8: Hi ni1998! We are glad that
column9: Hi ni1998! We are glad that you are finding support here on the NEDA forums. A portion of your post was edited due to the mention of specific behaviors and wording that may be triggering to other forum members. Our community guidelines are always available to review here http://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/community-guidelines. In the event you need further assistance please call the NEDA helpline at 1-800-931-2237 (M-Th 9-9 F 9-5 EST). Again, thank you for posting, and we hope you will continue to do so!

column4: Am i wrong to hold on to the past?
column5: Ok so i suffered with ednos when i was in school, I’m back to the way i was before ednos now for the past 4-5 years (well as much as i can be). But when i was suffering i was workin out on a cross trainer and it was contributing to losing weight. I haven’t used the cross trainer since those days but me and my boyfriend argue all the time about it because it takes up a lot of room and doesn’t get used. He says if I don’t get rid of it then he will. I know he’s right because it doesn’t get used. But it feels like safety for me if you get what i mean? I feel like i need to have it here whether i use it or not, just in case. I get really upset because I don’t want to get rid of it even though I don’t have the motivation or time to go on it. But i was wondering if anyone has this problem? I tried explaining it to him but we weren’t together when i was going through it all so he just doesn’t understand. Am i so wrong for wanting to keep it?
